The speech read as follows-

The Bill makes a number of rather minor amendments to the Patents Act 1952. Most of them are to set up procedures for handling patent applications which relate to nuclear technology. The procedures are needed to ensure compliance with the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 (the Safeguards Act) which was passed earlier this year.

The new procedures introduced by the Bill relate to patent applications which contain information of a kind referred to in the definition of `associated technology' in the Safeguards Act. The Safeguards Act provides that associated technology is not to be possessed or communicated without the relevant permit or authority from the Safeguards Office.

Under the Safeguards Act, `associated technology' means a document containing information that is primarily applicable to enrichment of nuclear material, reprocessing of irradiated nuclear material, production of heavy water or nuclear weapons, or nuclear information that is covered by an international agreement and is declared by the Minister to be information for the purposes of this definition. A document is defined to include a photograph, model or other thing from which the information may be obtained. Information publicly available is excluded from the definition.

Clause 4 of the Bill provides for the Commissioner of Patents to refer a specification which appears to contain this kind of information to the Director of Safeguards. If the Director is satisfied that the specification does indeed contain information of the defined type, the Director can send a certificate to that effect to the Commissioner. The Safeguards Office will also check whether the necessary permit and authority to possess and communicate the information had been given. In a case where it emerges that they had not been given, the Director's certificate can include a direction that the patent application is to lapse.

The Bill also enables the Commissioner, on the basis of the Director's advice, to take appropriate steps to prohibit or restrict publication of the information contained in a specification. There is provision in clause 4 for restoration of a lapsed application where the applicant's default is subsequently rectified by obtaining the necessary permit and authority. Clause 9 makes various provisions for aggrieved applicants to apply for review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of a decision of the Director or Commissioner. Clause 2 imposes an obligation on Safeguards Office staff to observe the usual confidentiality requirements of the Patents Act.

The system set up by the Bill is not particularly complex. The reason its wording runs for a few pages is that the new procedures have to mesh into the provisions of the Patents Act, ensuring particularly that decisions affecting people's rights are taken in a fair and open manner. The number of patent applications which will be affected by the Bill is expected to be small, and the procedures will be handled within existing resources of the Patent Office.

Clause 3 makes an amendment consequential on clause 4. Clauses 5, 6 and 7 of the Bill make minor amendments to the Patents Act which are explained in the explanatory memorandum. Clause 7 corrects a drafting error which recently came to light.

The Bill is not momentous, but it sets in place necessary procedures to ensure that the Safeguards Act and the Patents Act operate in a complementary and harmonious fashion. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Extradition Bill 1987 and the Extradition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987. The principal function of these two Bills is to consolidate in one format the two existing Acts which deal separately with extradition to Commonwealth and other countries. The principal Bill will apply to matters which are already extraditable under existing legislation, regardless of whether the offence occurred before or after commencement of the new Act, and the consequential provisions Bill will preserve existing extradition proceedings. I will be talking about the principal Bill and hereafter any reference to `the Bill' will be to that Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the Bill consolidates two previous Acts is an indication of the dilemma that we face in regard to extradition proceedings around the world. That is because two systems of law operate in the world. There is a system of law derived from British common law, which is well known to us in Australia. We call that the common law and we understand it. We also have another system which is derived from Roman law and which is based on the principle of nationality and the principle that the state has a duty to its citizens, that the citizens have a duty to the state and that that gives the state complete authority over its citizens. Countries operating under the civil law are in a position to control totally the actions and activities of their citizens to the extent that they in general object to their citizens being extradited to another country to be tried for an offence. They try their own citizens for the offence committed in the other country.

The result of that in the past was that we had two Acts dealing with extradition, one which dealt with those countries which had adopted the principles of common law from the British system-mostly Commonwealth countries-and another which dealt with those countries which had adopted the Roman law principles, called civil law. The Government has, in effect, very largely adopted the civil law proceedings rather than the common law proceedings. That is why I shall be arguing very strongly that this Government is both incompetent and out of touch with the people and that that is demonstrated by these Bills.

As to the question of incompetence, let me make the point very clearly and simply. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in his second reading speech said that the legislation was the result of an undertaking that he gave to the Parliament in November 1985 to make an exhaustive review of our extradition laws. What he failed to mention was that in February 1983 the Stewart Royal Commission identified the requirement for these laws to be corrected and for our extradition procedures to be improved. The Government sat on that report and did nothing from the time it came to office until November 1985 when, lo and behold, Trimbole had escaped from our clutches and the Government rushed in its legislation to try to fix up that situation. At that time the Attorney-General said yes, he would come in with a Bill in due course to correct the situation totally, but there was this preliminary measure as a result of the Trimbole escape. We had to wait until October or November of last year for this Bill to be brought into the other place for debate. It has taken all that time, from when this Government came to office in March 1983, with the Stewart Royal Commission report before the Attorney-General for his consideration, for us to get this Bill. It is a clear indication of incompetence.

Let me turn to the question of the Government being out of touch with the people. I will go direct to a quotation from a Professor Shearer of the Faculty of Law of the University of New South Wales. I will quote his words, which I adopt. He says about this Bill:
It is offensive to our notions of justice that a person, (whether a foreign or an Australian citizen) can be extradited on the mere demand of another country without any evidence.

I believe that is a clear indication that this Government is totally out of touch with the people because if the people of Australia only realised what was coming in in this measure they would say, `No, Government, we do not want this. Mr Prime Minister Hawke, take this legislation away and tell your Attorney-General to redraw it'. What this legislation does is to confirm what the Government did back in November 1985; that is, to take away the right of Australian citizens to come before a magistrate when they are charged with an offence which is an extraditable matter and have an Australian magistrate consider whether there is, in fact, a prima facie case against them. That right of Australian citizens has already been taken away by this Government and that taking away is confirmed by this Government so that for all time, while this legislation remains in force, Australian citizens will be deprived of their right to come before a magistrate and say to the magistrate, `Look, this Government overseas does not have the evidence that would create a prima facie case against me and therefore it is not entitled to take me over there and try me'. I believe that if the Australian people knew what was going on in this legislation they would say to Mr Hawke, `Take it back, Mr Hawke. We don't want it. This is a right which we have always had until you took it away from us in November 1985. We didn't understand what you were doing in November 1985; we now understand and we don't want it. You are out of touch with the people. You don't understand the sorts of things that people in Australia really want. I will quote again from Professor Shearer:
It is offensive to our notions of justice that a person . . . can be extradited on the mere demand of another country without any evidence.

That is what this Bill does. What it does is bring an Australian citizen to a position where, if another country files certain documents-all it has to do is produce certain documents which I will come to in due course in the debate-an order can be made to extradite that citizen without the magistrate being satisfied in any way that there is, in fact, a case against him.

Again, as to the incompetence of the Government, let me say that the Attorney-General argued the case appallingly badly. This Government is clearly intent on reducing extradition in Australia to a mere formality without regard to the liberty of the individual and without regard especially to the liberty of Australian citizens. In the debate in the other chamber the Attorney-General was in some considerable trouble in endeavouring to establish his case. As I say, in the course of that debate he argued his case appallingly badly. I can do no more than again turn to Professor Shearer who has written to my colleague, Mr Peter Reith, the shadow Attorney-General, as to a number of the matters which arose out of the debate back in the other chamber. Professor Shearer stated:
The Attorney-General argued appallingly badly; he does not appear to understand the subject at all. His Department is clearly intent on reducing extradition to a mere formality . . .
The most egregious error of all made by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) was his trump card-
Professor Shearer then refers to the bottom of page 3073 of the Daily Hansard-
that `no European country has been able to extradite anyone from Britain for more than 40 years'.
Professor Shearer said:

This was in the context of his argument that the prima facie case requirement impeded extradition. This is just plain invention. From the figures available to me for the years 1971-1980, taken from the Review of the Law and Practice of Extradition in the United Kingdom commissioned by the Home Secretary in 1979 and submitted to Parliament a total of 69 extradition applications from European countries to the United Kingdom were successful and 26 unsuccessful. This ratio is not significantly different from the figures for U.S. applications to Britain in the same period; 19 successful, 8 unsuccessful.

As I have said, the Attorney-General stated in the other place that no European country had been able to extradite anyone from Britain for more than 40 years, and, as Professor Shearer points out, that is a pure invention. Professor Shearer goes on to refer to pages 3067-8 of the House of Representatives Hansard. He referred to something the Attorney-General said, which was:
. . . I was at a conference of Commonwealth Ministers in Harare. All of them-except the British-said that it was about time that they abandoned the outmoded British standard.
Professor Shearer said about that comment:

It is untrue that at the Harare Conference Britain alone stood out against abolishing the prima facie case requirements. The debates are marked ``Confidential''. I don't know that I can quote them. (I have them because I have been the Commonwealth Secretariat's adviser on the Commonwealth Extradition Scheme). The truth is that there was no enthusiasm by any Commonwealth country for Australia's proposal to abolish the prima facie case, and the question was quietly dropped.

There is no doubt that the European countries want us to abandon the prima facie requirement. But the Commonwealth countries, except for Australia, recognise that there is a need to retain the prima facie requirement because it is the thing which Australia has had for so many years as a result of our common law traditions. But this Government is quite happy to go along with the European traditions and abandon the security which Australian citizens have had for so many years as a result of our traditions of the common law.
I quote Professor Shearer further. He referred to page 3068 of the House of Representatives Hansard at which Mr Lionel Bowen said:
In fact we do not have treaties with the Eastern Bloc countries because we do not recognise their systems of justice.
Professor Shearer said:

Another blunder by the Attorney-General. We do have extradition treaties currently in force with the following Eastern Bloc countries: Albania, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland, Romania and Yugoslavia. They are all pre-War and we have not actually extradited to any one of them since 1945, but they are still valid treaties.

I do not think there can be any doubt-in fact I have established it-that the Attorney-General, on this matter, like most of the other Ministers in this Government, is incompetent. As Professor Shearer said, one must have some doubts as to whether the Attorney-General knows what he is doing or whether he is simply being led by his Department along a track which, in due course, Government backbenchers and other members of the Government will suddenly say: `Glory be! What did you do? How did you happen to go down that path? We didn't understand that that is what you were on about. We didn't realise that that would be the consequence'. There is another matter which I will come to in relation to the death penalty which will provide even more startling and horrifying consequences for the Government when we reach that stage of the debate.

As I have said, clause 19 of the Bill takes away the prima facie requirement of Australian citizens which they had until November 1985. I acknowledge openly that in November 1985, in the rush to get the legislation through, to close the door after Trimbole had escaped, the Opposition did not vote against the provision taking away the prima facie rule. But, having considered it and having understood it almost immediately, we said that we had made a mistake, it was ridiculous and we must return to the situation where Australian citizens are entitled to the privilege they have always had because of their heritage. At the committee stage I will move an amendment to clause 19 which covers our concerns.

Clause 19 provides that a request for extradition needs to be supported only by specified documents. There is to be no prima facie case. The prima facie test is the rule applied by lower courts in common law countries as to whether the prosecution has adduced sufficient evidence to warrant the accused being put on trial by a jury. We all know what that means. A person appears before a magistrate, the people putting forward the extradition case say to the magistrate, `Here is the evidence', and the magistrate considers it and says, `I have considered that and there would be a prima facie case for committal to a jury. So I will make an order allowing the extradition'.

But under clause 19 all that is needed to be done is to produce supporting documents which include a duly authenticated statement setting out a description of, and the penalty applicable in respect of, the offence. That is nothing. No evidence has to be given that a person has committed anything. The statement just has to say that that is the offence and that is the penalty. Then all that has to be produced is a duly authenticated statement-we know what `duly authenticated' means; that in some way or other it is declared to be correct-in writing setting out the conduct constituting the offence, setting out that it is alleged that a person did a certain thing. It sets out the conduct. No evidence is required to prove that he did that thing; it just has to be alleged that he did it. That is the basis on which an order may be made. A magistrate cannot refuse to make an order to have a person extradited. In my mind it is unbelievable that the Labor Party has introduced such legislation.

Professor Shearer also criticised the Bill because it does not include provisions for a general power in the courts to refuse extradition where it would be unjust, oppressive or incompatible with humanitarian considerations. That power rests with the Attorney-General only. In other words, when a person appears before the courts of our land, the magistrate, the judge, will have no discretionary power at all. That is to be taken away from him. Once the supporting documents establish the matters listed in the Bill, the magistrate must make an order. Even if he believes that it is outrageous that a person should be extradited for a particular charge, he has no power of discretion. The only discretionary power rests with the Attorney-General. Again, that is something for which Professor Shearer has, rightly in my view, criticised the Government and the legislation. Before I finish dealing with clause 19 I shall read from page 21 of the explanatory memorandum just in case there is any doubt that what I have said is correct:

Sub-clause (5) makes it clear that the issue of a person's guilt or innocence is not relevant to extradition proceedings and that accordingly evidence to that effect may not be adduced by the person or received by the magistrate.

I turn now-my time is running out-to another matter of absolutely major concern under this Bill. Under sub-clause 22 (3) there is a new provision which prevents the Attorney-General consenting to an extradition application where the death penalty can be imposed for any offence for which extradition has been requested unless Australia receives an undertaking from the requesting country that either the death penalty will not be imposed or, if imposed, will not be carried out if extradition is granted. That all sounds fine. Let me say right at the opening of my remarks on clause 22 that I am opposed to the death penalty: I do not believe the state should take away the life of a citizen. That is a high principle. The clause says that where the offence in the other country is punishable by death the person is not allowed to be extradited to that country. So the person-and it is not just Australian citizens; the person, whether he is an Australian citizen or a foreign national living in Australia-is not allowed to be sent back to that country for trial on that offence where the death penalty may be applied.

I suppose in the case of some person who murdered a member of his family in the sorts of circumstances in which one would have some feeling that he might have had an excuse, one's heart may bleed for such a person and one might say that the death penalty should not be applied. But what would one do if the foreign national in this country was a terrorist who had, say, hijacked an aircraft in one of the southern States of the United States of America, say Louisiana, and blown up 150 people and then escaped and somehow arrived in Australia? This person has destroyed an aircraft with innocent people on board and the State of Louisiana, which is one of the 37 States of the United States which retain the death penalty, says it wants him back.

Under this legislation the Attorney-General has no right to sign an order allowing that person to be extradited back to that State in the United States unless it gives an undertaking that it will not enforce the death penalty. How could we possibly get such an undertaking? This provision is an absolute nonsense. There would be no way that in those circumstances we would be able to persuade that State to say, `Yes, send that terrorist back here and we will not execute him if we find him guilty of this offence'. Of course it is a nonsense. As I said, the problem is that no one on the other side has really applied his mind to this question.

Let me go a step further: the Government has said, `If he is in Australia he will probably be guilty of some immigration offence, he will be here unlawfully, so we will be able to get rid of him in that way'. So we are going to take this terrorist and export him to somewhere else in the world because he has committed an immigration offence-not because he is a terrorist but because he has committed an immigration offence or he is here unlawfully. What if he is here lawfully? He may be married to an Australian citizen and so be entitled to be in Australia. What will we do then? We are stuck with him. Under these circumstances the Government says, `Well, we have a provision in here whereby we can prosecute him in Australia for the offence'. Does the Government really want to prosecute a terrorist in Australia for committing some offence overseas? Do we really want a member of the Baader-Meinhof gang to be held in our gaols for life as a result of some offence committed overseas? Glory be, if that happened every Qantas Airways Ltd aircraft travelling around the world would be at risk of being hijacked by other members of the gang. Every Australian citizen around the world would be fearful of his or her life because this Government was holding some terrorist on certain charges.

We have to face the situation if an act of terrorism is committed in Australia. But we do not want to face it if that act occurs somewhere else around the world because of the death penalty provision which is in the extradition Bill. If the death penalty is bad enough, what about those countries which chop off a person's hand for stealing? There is nothing in the legislation about not being able to extradite people to countries which have such penalties. So it is all right to send people back to have their hands chopped off but we will not send them back if the death penalty applies. This means that we have to keep drug dealers here because some Asian countries have the death penalty and apply it.

The Government has not thought this matter through. There is no discretion in the legislation. There is a total prohibition on extradition if the death penalty applies in the country to which a person is to be extradited. The legislation will result in effect in making Australia a haven for major international criminals. This will be the place to come. All a person who commits a crime in a country which has the death penalty need do is whip off to Australia. A person who can get into this country somehow or other legally can stay here in the sure knowledge that he will not be extradited. People who have not committed some offence in regard to immigration laws will be able to stay in Australia safe from prosecution.

Do we want to make Australia a haven for international criminals? That is what this legislation does. Let there be no doubt about that. I do not understand why the Government is introducing this Bill in this form. The legislation would perhaps be satisfactory if the Attorney-General had some discretionary power in all the circumstances to say, `Well, look, in these circumstances I am not prepared to exercise this discretion; I am prepared to allow the person to be extradited'. But the Attorney-General himself has no discretion. No one has any discretion under this Bill. It is a nonsense. A discretion is not provided for because the Government does not have the political courage to exercise a discretion in particular circumstances. It is better to be able to hide behind the legislation and say, `No, we are not going to allow this person to be extradited because there is a death penalty over there. There is nothing that I can do about it because that is what the Act says'. If the Attorney-General had a discretion, he would have to exercise it. He would be responsible to the people of Australia for the exercise of that discretion. This is why the Government will not allow the Attorney-General to exercise a discretion.

I doubt whether I can say any more about this aspect of the Bill. I note that my time has almost expired. The people who have come to understand the significance of this legislation are making massive representations to us saying, `Please try to stop this in some way'. In particular I refer to the Minister for Justice and Attorney-General of the State of Queensland who has written to us, Senator Haines and the Attorney-General saying, `Please, do you understand what you are doing to this nation?'. I say to the Government, `Please rethink this. Adjourn this legislation. Take it away and have another thought about it because, quite clearly, you are incompetent and out of touch with the people of Australia and you are just, frankly, wrong'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Extradition Bill 1987 is an attempt to consolidate Australia's extradition laws by combining two Acts-the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act and the Extradition (Foreign States) Act. The consolidation process involves the elimination of unnecessary duplication, inconsistencies and deficiencies. Essentially, the legislation provides that people accused or convicted of terrorist type offences shall not be entitled to the benefit of the political offence exception to extradition. This is an interesting area. In the past there has been a fair amount of litigation surrounding the definitional problems arising out of political offences. By removing terrorists from that provision, I think the Bill has gone a long way towards clarifying the political offences category and, hopefully, will assist significantly in solving some of the problems that have arisen in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: Another pleasing feature of the legislation arises from clause 45, which will allow Australia to refuse to extradite its nationals when the country requesting extradition adopts this approach in relation to its own nationals. In those circumstances the Bill allows Australian authorities to prosecute that person. For the first time in our extradition laws we have established true reciprocity with other countries.

The Bill also places some restrictions on the granting of bail. Under this Bill magistrates are not permitted to remand a person on bail unless there are special circumstances. This provision is clearly necessary because experience has shown that people who are sought for extraditable offences often abscond. Quite often, for example, these people are in Australia to avoid arrest in the country where the alleged offence was committed. The other aspect of this provision is to prevent bail shopping-that is, to make a fresh bail application to another magistrate when the initial application is refused. The overall effect is to create a presumption against the granting of bail. Given the number of wealthy drug dealers who have absconded in recent years, many of whom have no ties to Australia, these amendments are eminently sensible. I believe that the provisions will help to maintain other countries' confidence in our ability to meet our extradition obligations. This particular matter will possibly be the subject of some discussion in the committee stage. I understand that, although they have not been circulated, some honourable senator will be circulating amendments with regard to the restriction on bail. I leave any further comments about that particular aspect until the committee stage.

This Bill also continues a provision introduced in 1985 which permits a person to consent to extradition and thereby obviate the need for proceedings. Linked to this provision is another which allows a person being sought to consent to being tried on return for offences for which extradition cannot normally be granted. I think this is a useful development. Of course, one often finds that a person who is accused of an extraditable offence may also be accused of other offences in the other country which is seeking the extradition order. At the moment it is not possible for that other country to try the person with regard to those other offences under the extradition warrant. What we have here, I believe, is a benefit to the defendant. If he or she so opts, that person can stand trial for all outstanding offences for which he or she is surrendered. Then, of course, there is the possibility, if they are done under the one operation, of concurrent sentences. Because the Bill requires the requesting country to list all extraditable and non-extraditable offences the person who is being sought will have a complete understanding of the charges that he or she can be expected to face upon return.

Whilst we acknowledge the explanation of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) the Australian Democrats note with some concern that access will be denied to the administrative review mechanisms under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, the ADJR Act. We have in the past commented on this Government's propensity to deny such access in relation to a reasonably large number of Bills that the Government has brought in. However, having regard to the totality of the Bill, we made a judgment that since the Bill contains an enhanced system of review and appeal procedures, designed to ensure that the denial of access under the ADJR Act does not leave a person without recourse to proper review procedures, the Bill should proceed in that particular item in the form in which it has been introduced. The Government can, however, rest assured that we will be keeping an eye on this matter and particularly on how the procedures are going to operate in practice. We will seek to restore the operation of the ADJR legislation if it seems necessary, as a result of experiences, that the review mechanisms in this Bill are either inappropriate or ineffective.

Another innovation in the provisions of this Bill relates to temporary surrender. A person serving a term of imprisonment for an offence against an Australian law may be temporarily surrendered to another country to stand trial there for an extraditable offence, and then returned to Australia to complete his or her sentence here, and ultimately be resurrendered to serve any sentence imposed as a result of the trial which came about because of the extradition. In addition to these matters Senator Lewis used an analogy about the chopping off of arms. I am not quite sure that I followed his analogy since extradition will be prohibited unless the Attorney-General is satisfied that the person will not be subject to torture. I would have thought that that is likely to come under that item in the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Torture usually precedes an offence. It is not subsequent to an offence.
—The honourable senator was talking about a person having his arm chopped off as a result of being convicted of a crime of theft.
—Yes, but torture precedes the offence. That is how they get the admission, is it not?

—My reading of the Bill-and I would be interested in the response of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to this-is that it is a blanket operation. A further safeguard-I certainly see it as a safeguard-exists in the statutory prohibition on extraditing persons from Australia to face charges in respect of purely military offences. Just as significantly, extradition is to be precluded, as Senator Lewis has already said, where the death penalty can be imposed for any offence for which extradition is granted. Unless Australia receives an undertaking from the requesting country that either the penalty will not be imposed or, if imposed, will not be carried out, extradition will be refused.

SPEECH.PARA: One can certainly imagine a range of problems arising in this area. However, I applaud the Government for taking this step. There is in fact a worldwide movement, not limited to Australia or to Commonwealth or even common law countries, towards abolishing the death penalty. It seems to me that Senator Lewis is suggesting that Australia, by taking part in this exercise, should be totally free from any problems. Unfortunately, the world is not like that. Many of Australia's attempts in this area, in terms of its international obligations, do have penalties. I draw Senator Lewis's attention to the attitude we take to South Africa. Undoubtedly that has penalties for Australia with regard to trade and other matters. This country does suffer penalties in its pursuit of worthwhile aims. It would be nice if the world were such that in this pursuit of worthwhile aims one never suffered; unfortunately, that is not the case. We support very strongly Australia's contribution to the international campaign to abolish the death penalty by the inclusion of this particular clause. I think it signals very clearly and unequivocally where Australia stands on this matter.

Clause 19 of the Bill provides that a request for extradition needs to be supported only by specified documents. Senator Lewis has circulated a number of amendments that he proposes to move in the Committee of the Whole, and therefore I do not propose to say anything more about that matter at this time except to indicate that we will not be accepting the amendment with regard to prima facie evidence. But I will leave the debate to the committee stage.

It is important for the Senate to realise that with extradition we are in a two-way street. We are dealing with other countries; we are dealing in areas where we wish to be able to get hold of those people who have committed crimes in Australia and who have fled to other countries. Likewise, other countries have exactly the same desire. Therefore, we have to negotiate in the treaty area for a workable arrangement. We do not want recurrences of the Trimbole exercise in Ireland. At the end of the day we will certainly be facing a trade-off. I suppose we are confronted with trade-offs everywhere in the area of justice. We have to address ourselves clearly and precisely, on the one hand, to rights of the defendant and, on the other, to the rights of society. When making judgments as to what positions one should take, we must realise that people of goodwill tend to arrive at quite different conclusions.

I must say that, as a result of committee hearings I have been involved in for some time now and experiences I have had, I have become more and more aware of the enormity of crime within our society. This involves not just the murder, the break and enter or the armed robbery. Although that is bad, it is something for which the society and the police have always had at least adequate protection and prosecution mechanisms. The type of crime with which we are now dealing, and against which the Senate has accepted that we require increased and special powers, is organised crime, particularly in the area of drug offences.

This chamber has accepted that we should establish a National Crime Authority, quite specifically, and with specific powers which exceed those which we have given to any other body in this country. It was not without some heartache and concern that we established the National Crime Authority. It is interesting that we are having this debate today, when the Victorian police have said quite clearly with regard to apprehension of alleged drug dealers this morning that that particular operation was only possible because of the National Crime Authority's powers. In other words, we have had to move towards the rights of society in this matter, away from the other pole, as it were, of the rights of the defendant. We have had to recognise that society did not have sufficient protection against organised drug traffic of the most horrific kind.

If we are to be effective in the fight against that type of crime-which affects not just a few people in this society, as some seem to imagine, but the entire society, and which results in massive corruption in police forces, in the judiciary and in public life-we must be willing to confront it and take stern measures against it, otherwise we shall be condemned by our society. So in dealing with these matters, of which this Extradition Bill is one-for, fairly obviously, the types of crimes about which we are talking in terms of extradition are serious crimes-we probably have to look again at where we have made the balance with regard to the people who are alleged to have committed crimes and to the rights of the society to be protected against crimes.

It is interesting to consider a judicial inquiry in my own State which started out in a relatively small area. Once one starts to tap into any one of these areas of organised crime, one finds that the connections to so many other areas immediately come forward. We have seen the most senior of police admit to corruption. We can sit back and wave our arms around and say, `We can't do anything about this', or we can seek to take whatever additional measures we are able to take-bearing in mind our desire always to maintain a system which is just and which will not end up in the conviction of innocent people. But we cannot go down that particular track unless we are willing to co-operate with as many other countries as possible, be they common law countries or civil law countries, with regard to treaty arrangements and unless we maintain a reasonable opportunity for countries to be able to extradite those people who are alleged to have committed crimes in their own countries.

So essentially, in terms of the extradition procedures, what we have moved towards here is not establishing guilt or innocence at extradition hearings, not conducting a trial, not testing the evidence under cross-examination, but, indeed, towards a situation in which those people can be taken into a certain type of legal system. I remind honourable senators that we have extradition treaties only with those countries that we believe have a legal system in which we are able to have faith. I found it rather odd that Senator Lewis should trail across the debate the fact that we had treaties with a number of Eastern bloc countries before the war. It is a lacuna of history that we seem to have ignored that the war caused an enormous change to the social, political and legal systems of those countries. Let me say that they are still in force.

There are plenty of treaties reaching back into the last century which we still have in force, because they have not been abrogated, with countries that do not exist. Lots of nonsenses still float around in international treaties. But we are talking about the day-to-day reality. Unfortunately, there is too much day-to-day reality in the spread of crime and corruption throughout our society. We will seek extradition under the terms of this Bill only with those countries which have a judicial system that we believe provides a fair opportunity for a person to be found innocent at the end of the day, and not have his life and livelihood put at jeopardy within a system which does not embody the principles that we hold so dear.

The Australian Democrats support the Government's approach to this issue. It is an important measure which will go a long way towards remedying a number of serious deficiencies that have appeared in innumerable trials in the past, where notorious criminals have been able to wander at large while non-operative treaties gathered dust in the Attorney-General's drawers-or if the new Attorney-General does not have drawers in the bottom of his desk, gathering dust on his shelves. We welcome the improvements and hope they will work. We will be facing further amendments to this Bill in the future as the Government seeks to broaden our extradition treaties with other countries and as we seek to make more efficient and effective this aspect of our fight against organised crime. We have to think seriously-and I hope the Opposition has-when it comes to the committee stage about where we draw that balance with regard to the fight against crime. As yet, I am not convinced that we have been able to give society sufficient weapons to make a massive inroad into that cancer which is continuing to spread throughout our society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address some remarks not so much to the Extradition Bill in its totality but to one aspect of it which was subject to comment by my colleague Senator Lewis in his remarks earlier this morning. I refer to clause 22 (3) (c) of this Bill. For the information of the Senate, that clause, as Senator Lewis has already pointed out, refers to the circumstances in which the Attorney-General receives from a foreign state a request for extradition of a person currently resident in Australia against whom there is alleged a crime for which there is prescribed in the country requesting extradition the death penalty if a verdict of guilty should be found against that person.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 22 deals with the question of determination by the Attorney-General of whether surrender should be made under extradition treaties in force between states at the time. Sub-clause (3) provides:
. . . the eligible person is only to be surrendered in relation to a qualifying extradition offence if:
(c) where the offence is punishable by a penalty of death-by virtue of an undertaking given by the extradition country to Australia, one of the following is applicable:
(i) the person will not be tried for the offence-
even if he is extradited; that clause does not seem likely to be used very commonly-
(ii) if the person is tried for the offence, the death penalty will not be imposed on the person-

even though it may be prescribed in the legislation of the country concerned; in other words, some kind of pre-trial, almost plea bargaining process, or something akin to that, would already have occurred-
(iii) if the death penalty is imposed on the person, it will not be carried out.

In other words, there is a guarantee that the sentence will not be carried through. If any of those circumstances is applicable, the clause is inoperative, but if none of those conditions apply then, where the offence is punishable by a penalty of death, this Bill makes it mandatory, not just optional or discretionary, for the Attorney-General to refuse extradition.

Before proceeding to my more general remarks on this clause I want to emphasise and make my position very clear. My attitude to this clause-I suggest it ought to be the attitude of any thoughtful person and, by definition, that obviously embraces all members of this Senate-has nothing to do with whether one believes in the death penalty for certain serious crimes or not. What I am talking about are questions of principle as to the ways our laws ought to be constructed. Having said that, I do not wish to conceal from the Senate and from you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I personally believe the time has come-indeed, I believe it is overdue-for a review to be undertaken by the Government of the previously very sweeping views about the appropriateness of the death penalty which some years ago resulted in its total abolition throughout every jurisdiction in Australia.

In the case of certain specified crimes and in certain specified circumstances-and those crimes and circumstances would be much narrower than those previously specified in most of our jurisdiction for the application of the death penalty-I happen to think that the restoration of the death penalty, although not, I emphasise, by hanging, which I happen to regard as a particularly ghastly method of execution, would be appropriate. In saying that, I also remark that that happens to be the view-not that I depend upon this in any way for my own position-of a considerable majority of Australians. Every opinion poll taken over the past decade indicates that the considerable majority of Australians are in favour of the death penalty in certain specified cases, including-I say this for the information of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who is in the chamber-a significant majority of Australian Labor Party voters.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you would also be well aware from your own experience-as indeed would all honourable senators in this place-that there is growing anger and revulsion in the Australian community at the growth in the murder rate, particularly where such murders are accompanied by other extraordinary crimes such as rape, other forms of bestiality and behaviour of that kind, of which the Anita Cobby case is perhaps the most striking, terrible and tragic of recent times. However, I say these things not only to make my position plain but also in order to make it clear that my remarks on clause 22 (3) (c) of the Extradition Bill 1987 have nothing to do with those things. Whether one is in favour of or opposed to the death penalty is totally irrelevant to the attitude which one should bring to this clause. At the outset, I note that that does not seem to be the view of the Government. It is difficult to ascertain what its view really is. The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in his second reading speech on the Bill in the other chamber simply said in relation to this clause

The Bill also introduces important new principles, most of which add to the safeguards afforded to people whose extradition from Australia is sought. It is these new safeguards which I regard as the most important elements of the Bill.
After some intervening comment which is not relevant to this point, the Attorney-General went on:

The second new safeguard is to preclude extradition where the death penalty can be imposed for any offence for which extradition is granted. Unless Australia receives an undertaking from the requesting country that either such penalty will not be imposed or, if imposed, will not be carried out, extradition will be refused.

As I said earlier, under the terms of this Bill, it would be mandatory that such refusal be given. With great respect to the Attorney-General that is not a reason; it simply tells us what the Government proposes.

Therefore, in search of more explanation of the Government's somewhat ill-thought out position-my colleague Senator Lewis has also made that point-I turned to the explanatory memorandum which accompanied this Bill in the other place as, invariably, explanatory memoranda accompany all legislation introduced in these chambers. Turning to the relevant pages 25 and 26 of that explanatory memorandum I find that subclause (3) provides that the Attorney-General shall not decide that a person is to be surrendered if any qualifying extradition offence attracts a death penalty unless an undertaking is given. It then goes into the exceptions to which I have already referred. With respect-although in this case I have not much respect for those who drafted this explanatory memorandum-I would have to say that, in terms of explanation, it is hardly what I call a very full and wide-ranging coverage of the reason for the clause. In fact, all it does is state what the clause does. If one can read the clause one does not have to read the explanatory memorandum because it does not add anything to what is in the clause.

In further pursuit of the Government's reasons for this particular provision I looked at the Hansards for the other chamber. The Attorney-General was no more helpful when responding to my colleague the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peter Reith, on this clause in the committee stage of the Bill. So far as I can see from my reading of the relevant sections of the Hansard, the responses by the Attorney-General on this issue were, at that time, both evasive and confused.

I will set out the problem as I see it. Senator Lewis has already spoken at some length about this matter although he covered the Bill as a whole much more widely. I want both to support his remarks on this particular clause and, in some respects, elaborate upon them. In doing so, I put it to the Senate that this clause raises very serious questions which properly transcend party politics. As Senator Lewis has said, the Government simply has not thought this proposal through. So far as the Bill as a whole is concerned, indeed, as Senator Lewis said, there is a good deal of evidence to suggest that the Government has taken a very long time to bring forward legislation on this matter which was first recommended by the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking as long ago as 1983.

Be that as it may, it is clear to me that, in this area at least, the Government has not thought through the consequences of the proposals which it has now included in the Bill. What it has simply done, as it has done so often in these matters, is to throw another bone to its Left faction. The members of the Left believe-and they are entitled to their views; I do not suggest otherwise-that there is something peculiarly abhorrent about the death penalty and that it should not be imposed for any crime, no matter how abhorrent that crime may be or how much forethought went into it. They believe we should not only apply that view within our own jurisdiction but also seek to impose it upon other jurisdictions.

Let us look at the magnitude of the problem. I think I am correct in saying that, while we do not have a death penalty on the books of any jurisdiction in Australia at present, many Western democratic countries, countries whose claim to be called democratic could not possibly be challenged, do have it. I am informed that 37 of the 50 American States, as well as the Federal Government of the United States of America, retain the death penalty for certain crimes; Canada does so; the Republic of Ireland or Eire does so; New Zealand does so, as does the United Kingdom. All of those countries retain capital punishment for treason as well as for certain military offences. A number of European countries, such as Belgium, Spain and Greece, also retain the death penalty for certain offences.

I am informed that at present there is a debate in the Canadian House of Commons. The Minister for Justice might like to refer to that point in his response to the debate. A month or two ago there was a debate in the Canadian House of Commons sponsored by the Government of Canada on the possible reintroduction of capital punishment for murder. At that time it was believed that there was a strong likelihood that if a vote were taken, Canada would restore the death penalty. I do not know the outcome of that debate. I mention it solely to indicate that in other parts of the world where, as I said before, no possible challenge could be sustained to the democratic nature of the countries concerned, some second thoughts are occurring on some of these matters.

I am not suggesting that persons against whom extradition proceedings are brought for the alleged committal of crimes for which the death penalty is prescribed in the countries concerned should be automatically extradited. The Attorney-General does and should retain a complete discretion to refuse extradition if he is satisfied that there are good grounds for doing so. If, for example, in the Attorney's opinion, after advice, there is a risk of a person being subjected to an unfair trial or being tried for spurious reasons, or where the offence is not recognised by civilised nations-an offence such as adultery, which in civilised nations would not be regarded as a capital offence-the Attorney-General would be expected to exercise his discretion. My point is that the power to refuse extradition in such cases should rest in the discretion of the Attorney-General and that that discretion should not be taken away from him, as this Bill would have the effect of doing.

Let me consider some possible examples of the kind of embarrassment to which the enactment of this clause would have the capacity to subject Australia in the future. Let us take the case of a man who murders several people in one of the States of the United States of America where the death penalty is prescribed for such conduct and then comes to Australia. There was a case not long ago of a Californian who murdered six women in the United States and then fled to Canada. Canada at present has in its laws the equivalent of clause 22 (3) (c) and had to refuse, because that was the law, to extradite this mass murderer to California because he faced the death penalty in that State. He might just as well have fled to Australia. If he were to do so after this Bill, including 22 (3) (c), becomes law, we will be facing exactly the same situation. If that is what the Government wants-if it really wants the kind of political storm, as well as the feeling of outrage on the part of the Australian community that I believe would result in such circumstances-let it proceed to enact this clause.

I hope nobody will tell me that in certain circumstances, although I do not think in this one, it would be open to the Australian jurisdiction actually to try such a fugitive in Australia. I understand that that would be possible in certain circumstances, but that is not what we are talking about in this case. That being so, the Government has simply not thought this measure through.

Let me take another example. Let us suppose an Irish Republican Army (IRA) terrorist assassinated a member of the royal family. As we all know, several years ago certain IRA terrorists assassinated Lord Louis Mountbatten. I am not sure whether he would qualify, for the purposes of what I have to say, as a member of the royal family, but that is a case in point. Under the British Treasons Act, the mandatory-not discretionary-penalty for such a crime is death by hanging. I leave aside the question of hanging. Let us assume that, having committed such an act of terrorism, the IRA terrorist makes his way to Australia, which course would be perfectly open to him if he was not apprehended at the time, and it is only after a lapse of some time that the British authorities determined that this was the man responsible for the assassination, track him down to Australia and seek his extradition from this country. Under this clause -I am not attacking the Bill as a whole-the Australian Government would be prohibited from permitting the extradition of that IRA terrorist to the United Kingdom unless the United Kingdom authorities were prepared to give one of the undertakings which I referred to earlier; namely, that, if the death penalty were imposed, it would not be carried out. But, as I have already indicated, the death penalty in this case is mandatory. The United Kingdom could not give such an undertaking without changing its law.

Let us consider the case of a Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) terrorist who assassinates an Israeli ambassador in one of the European countries-or any other country, for that matter-where the death penalty is prescribed for such an act of terrorism. We are well aware that acts of assassination directed against Israeli diplomats have been almost commonplace throughout the world in the last decade or so, even in countries such as the United Kingdom-where such an attempt was made a few years ago at the Dorchester Hotel-which are on the whole relatively free of such terrorist activity. Let us say that the terrorist slips away and travels to Australia-perhaps sponsored by Mr Bill Hartley, that well-known friend of the PLO, or perhaps by some of the PLO extremists who, under our current immigration policy, have been admitted into this country by successive Ministers for immigration in this Government during the past five years, particularly by the first of them, Mr Stewart West.

Let us assume that the country in which this act of assassination eventually took place eventually concludes that this is the man that they want, tracks him down and seeks his extradition from this country and that, under this Bill, we refuse to extradite him. One can imagine the effect upon public opinion, not only in the country where the crime was committed and not only in Australia, but also in Israel-a country with which we have a more than cordial, in fact, a very close relationship, particularly on the part of the Prime Minister personally-the country whose ambassador had been the victim of the terrorist act concerned.

I put it to the Senate that these are totally possible-not fanciful-circumstances which could arise in this country. Let us assume that I am wrong in that regard. The Minister may well suggest that in some cases, although I do not think in any of the cases I have specifically mentioned-I may be wrong in that regard; I will listen with interest to the Minister's reply-it would be open to the Government to take proceedings in Australia against the person for whom the extradition was sought. I pick up the point made on that aspect by my colleague Senator Lewis, who asked, I think very cogently: Are we really contemplating that, when a terrorist act of that kind has been committed elsewhere in the world, we will hold a trial in Australia for the terrorist and that, if in due course our courts convict him, we will imprison that person for life, 20 years or something of that kind? Surely we have learnt by the experience of the past few years that that kind of outcome is an open invitation to stepping up terrorist activity in our country. The whole history of the Baader-Meinhof gang in the Federal Republic of Germany has been that whenever a terrorist has been brought to book in that country and gaoled it is only a matter of time-a year, 18 months, 2 years, 2 1/2 or 3 years-before an attempt is made to free that person either by a direct attack upon the security of the prison in which the person is incarcerated, or by some kind of hostage operation in which the lives of innocent people are put at risk. I can see some smiles on the faces of some of the Minister's advisers. I suggest that they wipe them off their faces in these matters because I do not appreciate that kind of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I was talking to my adviser who was sitting next to Paul Conn at the time. There were certainly no smiles on their faces. I was engaged in conversation with them. There could not have been smiles on their faces. I think that that charge is totally unwarranted.
—Senator Stone, you are being heard in silence. I ask you to remain relevant to the Bill.

—I propose to conclude my remarks now. I thank the Minister for his intervention, but I maintain my position. Perhaps they were smiling at the Minister. Naturally, I defer to your ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President. Anyone who contemplates a procedure of that kind in Australia and the consequences which it would undoubtedly have for the Australian community must be totally irresponsible. I suggest to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and to the Senate that the Government has simply not thought through the consequences of this provision of the Bill. I hope that even in the limited time still available to it, it will do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on this most important legislation to do with extradition of fugitives alleged to have committed crimes. Of course, these are mutual matters. In other words, we are talking about persons who are found within the Australian jurisdiction and alleged to have committed some criminal offence in an overseas nation or persons who may have committed, it is alleged, a crime in Australia and who have fled overseas. The evident need for mutuality in any extradition treaty between nation states has always to be borne in mind. In fact, the need to conclude modern extradition treaties was highlighted by the Trimbole affair. There is no doubt about that. I acknowledge that. That is why the Parliament was presented with legislation in 1985 which was supported by the Opposition and which, amongst other things, did away with the requirement for the prima facie case in relation to the treaties that we were to negotiate. I will come to that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that extradition treaties are extremely important and that is why in only a matter of a week or 10 days I will be in the Philippines signing an extradition treaty with the Foreign Minister of the Philippines between our two countries in order to ensure that the South East Asian region does not become a haven or a safe retreat for those fleeing from Australia's criminal jurisdiction. At the moment it is regrettably the fact-I believe that Mr Costigan made this clear-that Australian criminals can purchase a ticket to Manila and flee the Australian jurisdiction when they think the heat is getting too much. Not only do they thereby escape Australia's system of criminal justice but, given their inclinations, they move into the underworld in the Philippines or in Manila itself and create a very bad impression in Manila of the types of Australians who undertake rackets and activities in that city. But with the new Government installed under President Cory Aquino, I am pleased to say that the frustrations in the negotiation process that have been experienced before have been set aside and a treaty is now about to be signed, I think within the next 10 or 12 days, depending on my program when I get to the Philippines. I believe that that is a very important example of the active, practical and effective steps which this Government is taking to ensure that in our region-let alone in many of the countries more traditionally thought to be havens for criminals such as those in South America and Spain-we do not have safe retreats available for those who have allegedly committed crimes in Australia. This is a very important matter.

The Philippines treaty has been drafted and is obviously ready for signature. The Philippines has accepted, naturally, even though I believe its criminal justice system is mainly characterised by common law characteristics-I cannot be absolutely confident because it has had a history starting with Spanish colonisation and then it was the United States influence, I presume, that brought in common law elements-and we have accepted that the prima facie case rule would not be suitable in its instance. It has also accepted that Australia can refuse to extradite an alleged criminal, a fugitive, to the Philippines, unless the Philippines gives an undertaking that the death penalty will not be imposed. So immediately we have an example of a treaty to be signed within the next 10 days or so where the matters of concern to the Opposition have not been, in any way, a barrier to the conclusion of these negotiations. The fact is that, in general, the extradition treaties are a very important part of our overall attack on organised crime. Indeed, as Senator Macklin quite rightly pointed out, these Bills are to be seen as part of the Government's overall attack on organised crime both domestically and in recognising not only international dimensions of criminal activity in Australia but also our international obligations to other nation states facing the same criminal activity.

This Parliament in 1985 was confronted with the proposal to remove the prima facie rule in order to recognise in a mutual, respectful, internationally proper way the different characteristics of mature, sound, fair legal systems which do not have within their traditions the sort of prima facie rule leading to committal proceedings that we have in our common law jurisdictions. It recognised the propriety in that situation of not insisting on the presentation of what we might call prima facie evidence to an Australian court which is being requested to agree to the extradition of a fugitive. That is a mature approach which I think ought to be commended to the Senate. I point out that it does not affect Commonwealth countries, except New Zealand. But in relation to Commonwealth countries, where there is a different scheme, the prima facie rule will still apply.

The fact is that on the basis of the bipartisan support then given by the parties in the Parliament in 1985, Australia has already signed 13 extradition treaties and has effectively concluded negotiations with another seven countries. A further 16 negotiations have proceeded on the basis of that statutory authority given by the Parliament in 1985. To accede to the Opposition's amendment now would be to alter unilaterally the ground upon which those negotiations have been concluded and effectively, in many instances, already brought into effect as treaties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that you can never alter the law in the future?

—No, I am not saying that. I am just pointing out that in good faith and with the knowledge that we had bipartisan support in 1985 we concluded many treaties and negotiations. I believe that on the basis of that, that undertaking and understanding, having been translated into those negotiations and treaties, ought to stand. There has been no good reason put forward for that not to be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting, too, to note that the United Kingdom Parliament currently has before it a criminal justice Bill which removes the requirement that foreign countries provide prima facie evidence in support of extradition requests. As I understand it, it is taking that step-as I suggest we should-in order to deal, in a more mature and respectful manner, with those very sound but differently constructed criminal justice systems on the European continent where, as Senator Lewis pointed out, the foundations of their jurisprudence are different from those within the common law. I believe that the amendment, to be moved by Senator Lewis on behalf of the Opposition, to insert provisions reinstating the prima facie rule, ought to be rejected by this chamber.

As far as the death penalty is concerned, I notice that despite the fulminations of the Opposition-or at least of Senator Lewis and Senator Stone-there is no actual amendment before the chamber whereby the Opposition would delete that statutory requirement that a person not be extradited unless the undertaking is given that, in effect, a death penalty will not be carried out if it is imposed as a sentence upon conviction for a serious offence in the requesting country. The fact is that there is no amendment before the chamber, which makes it all somewhat peculiar.

The answer to Senator Stone's question about why we should impose on other nations our view on the imposition of the death penalty was given by Senator Lewis. It is a metaphysical or an ideological stance, if you like, but he said that in his view it is improper-he was explaining why he opposes the imposition of the death penalty, even for serious offences-for a state to take the life of a citizen. I did not note it down but I think that is what he said. The honourable senator nods in agreement. That point of view is of such general metaphysical significance that once one forms that view and once a government adopts that view-as has the Australian Labor Party in conference and as have most Australian governments, as recognised by the fact that in no Australian jurisdiction is the death penalty available to be imposed upon conviction for even a very serious offence-the principle is so wide ranging and so generally applicable that it cannot be confined to the jurisdictions for which we have immediate responsibility. When an opportunity comes in international forums to make that position clear and indeed to negotiate for the recognition of that position-when another nation state is requesting Australian jurisdiction to give up a fugitive whom it alleges has committed a serious crime-we should take that opportunity to assert that general principle to which Senator Lewis pointed and make it part of our arrangements with those other nation states.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whatever the consequences for Australia?

—I can only agree with Senator Macklin that there will be instances where those consequences may occur, but because of the strength of the principle I have to say, `Yes, I believe that we have to accept some of those consequences'. In other words, if the principle is good in Victoria for Senator Lewis, it is good in Louisiana, to take his exact example. The example he gave was to do with the hijacking of an aircraft. I remind honourable senators that in the case of the hijacking of an aircraft and violence being done to passengers, the Australian courts could assume jurisdiction and deal with the offender. It is not as though the person would get off scot-free. In fact, we have an international obligation to deal with those persons who are found in our territory--
—That's what you want to do, is it?

—I do not want to do it. But I make this point. Senator Lewis gave the example of Louisiana in the United States. The officers have drawn to my attention the fact that there was an extradition from the United States of a person who was on what is called a murder 1 charge, I suppose the most serious intentional form of murder, in the state of California, which has the death penalty. I am advised that California gave the undertaking last year, and the person, whose surname is Bouras, was extradited. Our extradition treaty with the United States makes provision--
—That is not the question.

—I am just saying that it can work. In fact, the United States extradition treaty makes provision for that sort of process of negotiation to take place. I agree that there are complexities in the federal system. I am just pointing out that the Louisiana example might be dealt with in several different ways. But I do not believe it is a situation where one would be left without any redress against the offender concerned either within our jurisdiction or in the United States jurisdiction. Such an undertaking might be given as occurred in the Californian instance. We do not have an amendment before us so there is no need to say that we oppose it. I think I have given enough reasons to explain where we stand on that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the subject of torture which was raised, I am advised that we have a model extradition treaty. Article 32F of that model extradition treaty, which obviously we take into negotiations, states:

Extradition may be refused if the offence for which extradition is sought is an offence which carries a punishment of the kind referred to in article 7 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

I think article 7 talks about cruel, inhuman and degrading punishment. That clause has been taken into negotiations with, for example, Ecuador, Egypt, the Philippines, Uruguay, Indonesia, Venezuela and Argentina. So one can see in relation to that and no doubt in compliance with the torture convention which is to be introduced in statutory form into the Parliament possibly this session, that there would be good grounds for refusing to extradite somebody whom one thought would be subject to a punishment akin to torture in the sense of a dismembering of the person. I think we can deal with the question of new evidence at the time of review when we come to the committee stage. I do not think Senator Lewis spoke about this matter in his speech on the second reading.

I ask the chamber to support the second reading of this most important piece of legislation, which is part of a package not only to deal with the threat of organised crime to Australians within the jurisdictions for which we are immediately responsible but also as an aid to those other nation states around the world which themselves are threatened by the criminal activity which can undermine their societies and do such damage to their citizens. I commend the Bill to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
