SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the following amendment in respect of the Extradition Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 16, after subclause 19 (4), insert the following new subclauses:

``(4A) Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, in the case of all extradition applications the magistrate shall determine whether the evidence produced by or on behalf of the extradition country satisfies the prima facie evidence test.
``(4B) For the purposes of subsection (4A), a reference to the prima facie evidence test being satisfied has the same meaning as in paragraph 11 (5) (b).

``(4C) In determining whether evidence satisfies the prima facie evidence test, the magistrate shall receive any evidence produced by or on behalf of the extradition country that would be admissible in criminal or extradition proceedings before the courts of the extradition country.
``(4D) For the purposes of subsection (4C), evidence may be admissible if it is provided by or on behalf of the extradition country in duly authenticated form.''.

As has been made clear in the debate which preceded the committee stage of the Extradition Bill 1987, the amendments are to reinstate in the extradition procedures the old common law provision that when a magistrate considers an application for extradition he shall determine whether the evidence produced by or on behalf of the extradition country satisfies the prima facie evidence test. That is a fairly simple proposition and it goes to the heart of our common law tradition. It distinguishes clearly the difference between the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia on the one hand and the Australian Labor Party, and apparently the Australian Democrats, on the other. We have a firm and continuing belief in the common law heritage of the people of Australia, in the right which this nation's citizens have to ensure that they are not sent for trial on the basis of some documentation produced but can be sent for trial only after a committing magistrate has heard the evidence and determined that the evidence establishes a prima facie case for them to face trial in this country and, in an extradition case, in a foreign country.

After all, if Australian authorities decide to prosecute a person in Australia it is necessary for the prosecuting authorities to establish a prima facie case. But what this Government is saying is that if some foreign country wants to prosecute an Australian national or a person who happens to reside in Australia it does not have to establish a prima facie case; it simply has to produce documentation which, as I indicated in my speech at the second reading stage, contains this simple thing: a duly authenticated statement in writing setting out a description of, and the penalty applicable in respect of, the offence. `Duly authenticated' does not mean anything other than that a statement is sworn or declared to be a true statement; it just has to say that a particular offence exists in that country and outline what the penalty is. That is not something on which an accused person is in any way indicted.

The only other thing that has to be looked at by what I would call the extradition country is a duly authenticated statement. Again, it is just a matter of its being sworn. It is not a sworn statement as to the evidence but a sworn statement in writing setting out the conduct constituting the offence. Evidence does not have to be produced. Some person in authority-I think that the Bill lists who that person might be-in a foreign country just has to say, `Mr Jones committed the following offence by doing a particular thing'. The person making the declaration was not present and did not see Mr Jones commit an offence. There is no requirement to produce any evidence.

That is a massive departure from the traditions which the people of Australia have been brought up to expect will apply to them and, indeed, to all people charged in Australia with offences which are of a sufficient nature to warrant extradition. I am not talking about minor statutory offences. That fundamental principle-that common law heritage-is being overridden by the legislation. We say to the Government that it is wrong; the people of Australia do not want it to do this. Unfortunately, as we know, far too many people do not really understand the significance of the laws which have been passed by the Parliament until they or some close friend or relation are confronted with the result. Then they shake their heads in disbelief and say, `Surely the Labor Government did not do that to us. Surely it did not take away our rights'. I believe that if the people of Australia really understood what this was all about, if it could be tossed to them by way of a referendum or something like that, they would reject the proposal in favour of the retention of their common law right at least to have an Australian judge say, `Yes, there is a prima facie case to answer'.

I now turn to the two arguments raised by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in the other place in objection to our amendment. He said that the United Kingdom had abandoned the principle. That is not so in relation to Commonwealth countries. My understanding is that the United Kingdom has not abandoned that principle in relation to Commonwealth countries, but it has abandoned that principle for the European Economic Community (EEC), of which it forms a part. Because of its EEC obligations it had no choice but to be forced to go along with those countries in the EEC which have civil law. I do not see that that is an argument which should be followed in Australia. After all, the United Kingdom really had no choice because it is a member of the EEC. As I have said, it has retained the principle as far as it applies to extradition proceedings in Commonwealth countries.

In addition, the Attorney-General argued that the proposed amendment would require proof of the evidentiary laws of the requesting country in Australian courts. In other words, there would be a technical difficulty because every time such a matter went before a magistrate the extraditing country would have to appear before him and prove the law of the land to the magistrate's satisfaction. That is a specious argument. Honourable senators will see that the way in which we have drawn up the amendment provides that:
. . . evidence may be admissible if it is proved by or on behalf of the extradition country in duly authenticated form.
Honourable senators will also see the provision that:

. . . a magistrate shall receive any evidence produced by or on behalf of an extradition country that would be admissible in criminal or extradition proceedings before the courts of the extradition country.

If the Government were really concerned about the position but would accept our amendment, if we could overcome that difficulty, let me offer the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who is at the table, this suggested addition to the amendment: Admissibility of evidence may be proven pursuant to a certificate to that effect, produced by or on behalf of the extradition country and authenticated. I suggest a clause along these lines: `The magistrate shall receive any evidence produced by or on behalf of the extradition country that would be admissible in criminal or extradition proceedings before the courts of the extradition country'. I am saying to the Minister for Justice that there are ways whereby we could overcome this problem, if that were the Government's concern. What I am talking about here is the fundamental principle. Is there a difference between the members of the Australian Labor Party and, apparently, the Australian Democrats on the one hand and the members of the Liberal and National parties on the other hand, that we believe fundamentally in the prima facie rule and the Democrats and Labor Party members do not?

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendments proposed by the Liberal Party of Australia relating to the presentation of prima facie evidence. Had such evidence been admissible to the Australian courts in the recent Orionia case, two American citizens, Dr Hempel and Mr Etheredge, would not have languished in Canning Vale prison for 19 months. The associated questions of bail denial and seizure of the vessel, which I understand to be a Customs matter rather than a case for the Attorney-General's jurisdiction, are also of concern. Many Australians have been appalled at the imprisonment of these two American citizens, who ought to be considered innocent unless proved otherwise, and that bail has been denied to them. This is a denial of basic justice. Had prima facie evidence been presented to the Australian courts this case would have been settled long ago. If such amendments regarding prima facie evidence mean the renegotiation of extradition treaties with some countries with which we have agreement, so be it. To limit inconvenience to the Government and its bureaucrats is no excuse for injustices to continue. I therefore support the amendments put forward by Senator Lewis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 19, as it currently stands in the Bill, provides that a request for extradition need be supported only by specified documents. Normally, the documentation, as Senator Lewis has already said, would consist of a duly authenticated warrant and authenticated statements specifying the alleged offence and penalty as well as the conduct constituting the offence. What Senator Lewis did not then go on to say is that in some instances, and it is not ruled out by this Bill-this covers mainly common law countries, Commonwealth countries-there is an additional treaty obligation that a prima facie case be established, in which case it would be.

SPEECH.PARA: The provisions of this Bill whereby the liability for extradition is decided on the basis of documentation essentially continue procedures which were first introduced in 1985. It is interesting that the Opposition at that stage voted for them. If one takes Senator Lewis's words, presumably the Opposition was doing away with its support for a prima facie case to be established. One well knows why the Opposition supported the provisions in 1985; at that time there was a great clamour in the population to tighten up our extradition arrangements because we had just been involved in the Trimbole case and the Opposition was not about to stand out against that type of popular opinion.

There was a need then and I think the need continues now. As I argued at the second reading stage, Australia does need tough, workable extradition laws. Where we come down with regard to one pole or the other probably depends less on our emotional or other attachments to our history and more, I would have thought, on a realistic appraisal of the vast extent of crime moving through our community. In looking at each of these Bills we have an obligation to judge it on the situation before us.

Senator Vallentine raised some other matters with regard to the Orionia case, which has been settled in the High Court of Australia. Under this Bill, of course, a person could avoid all the extradition obligations and return to the country which is seeking the extradition to stand trial. In other words, there was not an obligation on those people to languish here; they could have returned and the case would have been completed. I assume the reason they did not want to do that is that they believed they would not have a fair trial in the country which was seeking their extradition. That is a totally different matter; it is a matter for them with regard to that particular country. They did not have to stay in Australia. They were perfectly free to go-in fact, we would have been quite happy for them to go-to the country seeking their extradition with regard to the matter of the boat and other items involved in the case.

Rather than try, as Senator Lewis did, to put opposition in the form of support for the traditional methods of common law, which we still support and which will continue in this country, we are looking at our relations with both common law countries and civil law countries and we have to weigh in the balance matters other than our particular type of judicial system. We have to have good working relationships on extradition with those countries if we are to battle the problem of organised crime, which of course does not sit inside any particular State in Australia; it does not sit within Australia, it sits over the entire world. It is not inhibited in any way by travel between countries or by the vast amounts of money that are required for these purposes. We are engaged in an international struggle against organised crime. We have to co-operate with many other countries around the world if that battle is to be won. I think this legislation is another arm to that battle. I think it should be seen in that light and not in the light in which Senator Lewis tried to show it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recognise the point that has been raised by Senator Macklin that it is very difficult to address the various mixes of judicial systems around the world. Not every country with which we have extradition treaties has our system. Nevertheless, we do have a system and the onus of proof surely is on the Government to establish reasons why we should depart from soundly based principles which are provided in our system, as were described by Senator Lewis. I have not heard in this whole debate any compelling argument advanced by the Government that would suggest that we depart from the requirement of a prima facie evidence test. I have not heard any argument by the Government that would convince me we should be departing from what is an essential feature of our system of justice. Extradition treaties quite clearly are political instruments which are established between executive governments of various countries. I believe it is very important to maintain as far as we can in the interests of individuals' freedoms and rights the separation of powers between the judiciary and the Executive, even on an international level.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vallentine has raised a very valid point. I acknowledge that a number of people may not have confidence in the system of justice operating in another country and they may be more confident that their rights would be more adequately protected under the system that we have here. People look to their rights being protected by our system of law while they are resident in this country. I would like the Minister in his response to the debate thus far to outline the particular cases which the Government considers are of such importance as would require or influence it to depart from what is a major tenet of our system of justice in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made some comment during the second reading debate-and I understand that Senator Harradine was engaged on other senatorial business at the time-about the fact that following the 1985 acceptance of the abolition, in certain instances, of the prima facie requirement, the Government engaged in negotiations with many countries, which I listed, and successfully concluded treaties of extradition with them. I pointed out that, for example, in the next 10 days or so I will be in the Philippines signing an extradition treaty with the Foreign Minister of that nation state which has itself accepted certain requirements based on the 1985 legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I am coming to is this: despite our adherence and devotion to the common law, there is a need when one is concluding arrangements with nation states around the world which, as the honourable senator said, share different jurisprudential cultures and different ways of approaching the trial, conviction and sentencing of an alleged offender, to acknowledge respectfully that other legal systems have their own soundness and validity. Those other legal systems of countries where a trial would take place-and we do not have extradition treaties with nation states which, in our judgment, do not have sound legal systems-find great difficulty in presenting the sort of evidence which is required in Australian common law jurisdiction by way of a prime facie case. Their legal systems are not geared to that sort of hearing. For example, Spain had such difficulty in its relations with the United Kingdom that it could not get anybody extradited from the United Kingdom. In 1978 it abrogated the treaty with the United Kingdom, which led to Spain becoming a haven for British criminals.

The point is that we cannot impose treaties on other nation states in order to achieve a situation where those who flee the Australian jurisdiction, having allegedly committed an offence here, can find a safe haven. We need to have extradition treaties with a range of countries, some of which do not share the common law appreciation of the trial method, which includes establishing a prime facie case. These nations will just not come to the party or be signatories to a treaty unless we make an adjustment and acknowledgment. This provision has been put in the Bill to enable us to conclude treaties with countries that have different jurisprudential bases.

Senator Lewis raised the question of the United Kingdom Bill which, although not passed into law yet, does exactly the same thing. This Bill, which is before the United Kingdom Parliament at the moment, distinguishes between Commonwealth common law countries and all other non-Commonwealth countries, not just European Economic Community (EEC) countries. It is not just a matter of the United Kingdom having some obligation because of the EEC arrangements. The United Kingdom Government and the House of Lords-and I have read some of the debates that have taken place-have given recognition to something which is at the heart of the common law tradition. It is the fountain of the common law tradition. The United Kingdom Government and the House of Lords, which includes the law Lords-people who appreciate the sorts of points that are being made-have nevertheless concluded that, as a part of their international treaty making in regard to extradition, this provision is suitable, helpful and efficacious in concluding treaties with other countries. It is for that reason that the Government will be opposing the amendment.

Senator Jo Vallentine raised the question of prime facie evidence not being made available in an extradition proceeding in which the state of Israel sought to extradite certain persons who were remanded in custody in Western Australia. That is not the case. Under the extradition treaty with Israel, the Israeli authorities had to provide evidence. Under the treaty the requested state has to produce evidence which would constitute sufficient evidence to justify a person being put on trial if the act or omission constituting the offence had occurred in that part of the territory. So there was a requirement. In other words, a treaty of extradition-in this case with Israel-can add that requirement if it is mutually agreed upon. That was the case. Prime facie evidence in that sense was required in that extradition proceeding.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Lewis's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) clause 22 of the Bill, which is the provision whereby, if the offence in the other country is punishable by a penalty of death, the following provisions are applicable: a person will not be tried for the offence; where the offence is punishable by a penalty of death, the Attorney-General will not surrender that person unless-
—Unless he gets one of three undertakings.

—Yes, unless he gets one of three undertakings. I want the Minister to confirm-so that the people of Australia understand that there is no question about it-that the Attorney-General has no discretion unless he gets one of those three undertakings.

—I beg the Government to rethink this provision, I appreciate that the Bill is now about to go through. —The Government has given consideration to these matters, including over the summer period when it received further representations, but intends-for all the reasons already outlined in my reply to the second reading debate-to stand firm on this provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I am not well qualified to speak on it, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That standing order 362 be deleted and replaced by the following standing order:
362. The publication of each document laid upon the table of the Senate is authorised by this Standing Order.
I have no idea what that means.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion which the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has moved.
—Do you have any better reason?

—From what the Minister has said, any reason would be a better reason. However, I wish to draw attention to something that seems to me to be worthy of some consideration, either by the Standing Committee on Procedure or by some report being given by the appropriate Senate officers. I refer to the significant difference which apparently exists in terms of the status of those papers which are tabled in the House of Representatives and those which are tabled in the Senate. As I understand it, one of the important advantages of a paper being tabled in the Senate is that when it is subsequently quoted from by a senator outside this place, it has attached to it the same sort of privilege as would exist if the senator were quoting directly from Hansard, whereas a paper tabled in the House of Representatives, if quoted from, attracts only a qualified degree of privilege.

SPEECH.PARA: This was particularly drawn to my attention yesterday, I think, in a matter in which Senator Tate would have some particular interest. In the House of Representatives, Mr Bowen tabled a couple of reports from the Australian Federal Police which dealt with a matter involving the Tina Wong case in New South Wales. I sought the advice of the Records and Table Office in the Senate about being provided with copies of those documents which had been tabled in the House of Representatives. The Records and Table Office here was kind enough to explain to me that, had these documents been tabled in the Senate, I would have been able to have made use of them and quoted from them in a particular fashion in relation to the question of privilege. The fact that they had been tabled in the House of Representatives attracted a degree of privilege which was in fact a lesser degree of privilege than that which derives from their tabling in the Senate.

I believe that this is an area in which there needs to be some attempt to reconcile the Standing Orders of the House of Representatives and the Standing Orders of the Senate, so that the documents in the possession of the Parliament should not have a different quality attached to them depending on whether they were documents of the House of Representatives or documents of the Senate. Similarly, I believe that in terms of tabled documents it would be of considerable advantage for the Procedure Committee to investigate the question of whether a document, having been tabled in one House, should automatically be notified to the other House as having been tabled and therefore being a part of the parliamentary record.

I recall a case in which a fairly significant document relating to a report by the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) was tabled in the House of Representatives and had a material bearing on the ASTEC report. That document, however, had never been tabled in the Senate nor had the Senate been notified that it had been tabled. Despite all of the attempts to investigate this particular ASTEC report, it was quite by chance that I noted that a paper had been tabled in the House of Representatives which was quite important in terms of the debate which subsequently ensued. This was a matter involving a financial transaction of ASTEC over which some debate occurred in this chamber between Senator Peter Walsh and me.

I think this particular standing order is a useful one in that it makes it quite clear that the documents which are laid upon the table of the Senate are authorised for publication and that we do not require a series of specific resolutions dealing with individual papers to give them the sort of status about which I have been talking. Therefore I very much support this motion. It is the laying down of a blanket rule about publication of all papers which have been laid upon the table of the Senate. But I draw attention to those two matters: First, the need to reconcile the differing Standing Orders in the House of Representatives and the Senate, which give a different quality of privilege to documents depending on whether they were tabled in the House of Representatives or the Senate. We therefore have to be somewhat careful about quoting from tabled documents to make sure that we understand the difference between the quality of privilege attached to those tabled in the House of Representatives and those tabled in the Senate. Secondly, there is a need for there to be greater communication between the two Houses in at least advising what papers have been tabled in one House which have not been tabled in the other House. People who have an interest in a matter will have that automatically drawn to their attention. It might be done by some sort of formal notification being printed in our Hansard in the same way that we print the list of the papers which the Clerks table each day, and have that list incorporated in Hansard, a list of papers might be made available that were tabled in the House of Representatives during the week, which were not tabled in the Senate, and that list included in the record; or there might be some other more appropriate fashion. I think this is something which could usefully be looked at by the Procedure Committee or form the basis of advice from Senate officers to the President, for him then to bring the matter to the attention of the chamber. But in terms of the specific resolution before us relating to a change in standing order 362, I support the proposal as advised by the Procedure Committee and as moved by the Minister for Justice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, I support this change. Standing order 362, which by virtue of this Standing Committee on Procedure report I read carefully for the first time this morning, is clearly not only ambiguous but also somewhat confusing. It states:

Therefore, the suggested alteration that has been put to the Senate is a new standing order 362, which is in a simple form and states:
The publication of each document laid upon the table of the Senate is authorised by this Standing Order.

This appears to be clear and unambiguous and therefore resolves the problem of privilege. It means that we can comfortably quote from tabled documents in the future without having to be concerned as to their status.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of matters have been raised in this debate. I propose to go, as best I can, to those matters and answer them.

SPEECH.PARA: It appears that the House of Representatives has taken a more restrictive view, and generally has not made tabled papers freely available.
It then goes on, and I think this picks up the point referred to by Senator Puplick:
This difference of practice is of little consequence, because any granting of access to a tabled document is a publication of the document, and the Houses differ only in the degree of publication.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean by `take on board'?

—Does the honourable senator want me to make a helpful comment on this? I will take them on board, report them to the Minister and the Minister will--

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Second Report of the Sixty-third Session

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Sessional Order, as contained in the attachment to the Report, be adopted:

That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, in a debate on a motion for the suspension of any Standing or Sessional Order a senator shall not speak for more than 5 minutes, and if the debate is not concluded at the expiration of 30 minutes after the moving of the motion the question on the motion shall then be put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak against this proposal that a sessional order be introduced to restrict the amount of time that can be devoted to debating the suspension of Standing Orders. At the outset, I say that I am a member of the Standing Committee on Procedure, and I voted against this proposal at the time it was considered by the Committee. The tradition of the Senate is that a debate on Standing Orders affords a free vote. It is not a matter of party discipline, so I look forward to some support from those thinking members of the Australian Labor Party who have turned their minds to this question.

SPEECH.PARA: I see this very much as a matter that relates to the ethos of the Senate, and its collegiate system. I well remember the time when I came in here as a new senator. I was sitting on the other side; we were in government then. One of those great senators of the modern age, Senator Reginald Withers, was sitting beside me. Somebody-I cannot remember whether from my own Party or the Labor Party-was carrying on interminably, speaking on a Bill. In those days, on non-broadcast days we were allowed to speak for one hour. I was impatient with the line of argument that was being developed and I said to Senator Withers, `Why don't we move that he be no longer heard?' He turned to me, with genuine surprise, and said, `You mightn't agree with what he is saying but he is certainly entitled to put his view, and he is entitled to be heard in the Senate'. In the 10 years I have been here I have learned to recognise the virtue of that point of view.

This chamber is unlike that of any other parliament in Australia. People are entitled to be heard. I see the suspension of Standing Orders restriction on time as very much a further erosion of our rights to speak in this chamber. In the time I have been here I have seen a marked reduction in the opportunity that honourable senators have to speak on issues. The procedure that we used to have of being able to speak on any subject at all on the first reading of a money Bill was a very important privilege that we had. It has now disappeared. The only opportunity that we now have to speak on a subject is that very abridged quarter of an hour on a non-controversial matter through lunch time on a Thursday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you agree, Senator, that that is a change of custom, not a standing order?

—It has been a change of custom, but the effect has been a reduction in the opportunities that senators have to debate and to bring a matter before the Senate. Despite the restriction in the opportunities that we have to speak in this place on matters of our choice, the amount of work we do or the efficiency with which we debate and process Bills through this chamber has decreased. I do not believe that we are putting as many Bills through as efficiently as we did before. I wonder whether that is not due to the fact that people are rising to speak on Bills, particularly in committee stages of Bills, on which they really do not have a burning urge to speak but just feel that they have to say something and the other avenues that they formerly had are denied them.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I may diverge for a moment, since we are talking about procedural matters. I support the view that has often been aired in all the time I have been a member of the Senate-that we spend too much time in the Senate debating, in second reading debates, matters which have already been fully debated at the second reading stage of Bills that have been introduced in the House of Representatives. I believe that, as a House of review, we should devote more time to the committee stages of Bills that are introduced in the House of Representatives. I, on most occasions, would support the view that the Opposition and the Government put down a formal statement of their support for or opposition to a Bill and devote most of the time for that Bill to the committee stage, where I think the characteristics of this chamber enable us to do a much better job than could possibly be done in the House of Representatives, which is driven by the mass of numbers and the need always to support the Government.

Let us turn to this particular case, because the proposition that the Procedure Committee has put before us is that when a motion is moved to suspend standing orders there be only 30 minutes in which to debate it. The motion to suspend standing orders is always taken as a matter of urgency. It follows, therefore, that there is a need to explain why the business of the Senate should be set aside so that this matter of urgency can be dealt with. There is a need for the senator moving the motion to explain why it is necessary. There is a need for his or her argument to be challenged by senators on the other side and for the points that are raised to be picked up by the supporters of the suspension and debated so that the Senate fully understands the point of view.
I should like to read the standing orders which cover the suspension of standing orders, in chapter XXXV, at present. Standing order 448 says:
In cases of urgent necessity, any Standing or Sessional Order or Orders of the Senate may be suspended on Motion without Notice:
Provided that such Motion is carried by an absolute majority of the whole number of Senators.
Standing order 449 reads:
When a Motion for the suspension of any Standing or Sessional Order or Orders appears on the Notice Paper, such Motion may be carried by a majority of voices.
Standing order 450 reads:
The suspension of Standing Orders shall be limited in its operation to the particular purpose for which such suspension has been sought.

Inherent in those three standing orders is the matter of relevance. It has always been a tradition of this chamber that no part of the debate on a motion to suspend standing orders shall stray from the point at issue before the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is unenforceable-that is the problem, is it not? It is almost unenforceable.

—No; with respect, Minister, you are quite wrong on that point. It is not unenforceable. I would agree that there are often areas of greyness. There are areas which require judgment, and indeed firm judgment, from the Chair. But it is in no sense an impossible task for the Chair to rule on those matters. Indeed, in all the time I have been here the authority of the Chair has never been a matter of issue. While I can concede that, in the heat of the moment, there may be times when very firm and decisive action is required from the Chair, such action is in no way beyond the attainment of the Chair. In the time that I have been here, I have never seen a President-the President is usually in the chair for the suspension of standing orders-faced with a situation which was beyond his control as a chairman. So I do not accept that the difficulties we face are difficulties that cannot be coped with by our present Standing Orders.

SPEECH.PARA: The Procedure Committee cited the House of Representatives and instanced in its report that the House of Representatives operates on the basis that a motion to suspend standing orders may not be debated for more than 25 minutes-the first two speakers being limited to 10 minutes and the other speakers to five minutes. As Senator Cook said a few minutes ago, what the House of Representatives chooses to do is its own business. We have no obligation to conform to its practices. Indeed, its practices are very different. I return to the point I made earlier in this speech: that the House of Representatives is driven by the tyranny of numbers; the Government always has the majority, and the Government must never be put at risk by losing a motion on the floor. So it is quite proper for the House of Representatives, if it decides to do it, to restrict its debate to 25 minutes. But it has absolutely no relevance to the Senate, and it is a complete irrelevance to bring it up.

Let us reflect on the practicalities of what happens when a motion to suspend standing orders is brought up. It is either a premeditated move in the Senate or it is not premeditated. In a large percentage of cases, it has not been premeditated. Whether or not it has been planned, the fact that someone in the Senate gets up to divert the Government of the day from the course of business it has published on the Notice Paper always produces a marked reaction. So the first thing that happens when one moves to suspend standing orders is that one creates turmoil in the chamber. To propose, as the Committee does in its report, that we have a restriction of 30 minutes total time, with each speaker being restricted to five minutes, is completely impracticable for reasoned debate. If someone on this side moves the suspension of standing orders, the first thing that happens is that there is uproar on the other side, there are interjections, and the speaker frequently cannot be heard for minutes at a time, and any way and any opportunity of developing a reasoned argument goes out of the window. It really is incumbent on the first speaker to lay out the basic reasons why standing orders have to be suspended. On a five-minute time scale, it is quite impossible to do that.

The reason why the Committee moved there was that the Australian Democrats decided that they did not want any debate at all on the suspension of standing orders. Despite the name of the Democrats, they are a very immature party from a democratic point of view. Their view of democracy is that provided that they are heard and their views are not challenged, we have a democracy. But as for defending their views in the robustness of this chamber, they are not very keen on that. They sought to pervert the great traditions of this chamber by removing the right to speak from the great majority of senators and, therefore, the great majority of the people of Australia.

I will argue very strongly that there is no reason at all for a limitation to be placed on the amount of time in this chamber when a motion to suspend standing orders is moved. For the 10 years I have been here, I have never seen a motion to suspend standing orders abused. I have always seen it used responsibly and used for a legitimate legislative purpose. I have no grounds for believing that that will not be so in the good judgment of the Senate in the future.

What is being proposed here is a variance of the practice of the Senate. It is not a matter of saying that we are relying on tradition in opposing this. What we are doing is looking back at the operations of this chamber and the experience we have had over 88 years, and the very strong belief we have in the right of individual senators to be heard, whether we agree with them or not. I seek leave, Mr President, to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! By arrangement, I propose that Question Time conclude just before 1 o'clock to enable Australian Broadcasting Corporation broadcasting commitments to be met. If Ministers have answers to questions asked earlier in the week, these answers may be given at 2 o'clock.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Home Affairs. I refer him to a staff circular dated 16 February 1988 from the Australian Electoral Commissioner, Dr Hughes, to all Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) staff, and tabled by me in the Senate yesterday, in which the Commissioner said, amongst other things:

QUESTION.PARA: A number of substantial defects have been identified in the returns and statistics relating to the 1987 election.

It now appears possible that the existing returns and statistics cannot be relied upon with any certainty. It has been established that in the areas where inquiries have already taken place, far too many figures are defective . . .
What is not known is the degree of accuracy of figures in the many areas which have not yet been tested.
A working party is being set up to recheck and recount the ballot papers and declarations from a sample of divisions.

Is the Minister aware that the Electoral Commissioner, in his circular, also referred to the disenfranchisement of electors by administrative errors, the denial to parties or candidates of public funding payments to which they are entitled and the loss of records that are required to be kept so that election results may be challenged? I ask the Minister: First, are these grave admissions those which he described in a Press statement last night as `possible minor inadequacies at the local level'? Secondly, if so, how does he explain the yawning chasm between his description and that of the Electoral Commissioner? Thirdly, did the Minister mean to imply that the Electoral Commissioner was wrong in his remarks, or was the implication accidental? Fourthly, why has the Minister failed to inform the Parliament on these serious matters, which cast doubt on the ability of the Hawke Government to guarantee fair elections? Fifthly, will the Minister now make a full and immediate statement to the Senate about this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I read a Press release from Senator Short. My first inclination was to look at the date of Senator Short's Press release to make sure it was not dated 1 April. For a long time I have noted the dichotomy between reality and fantasy in Senator Short's Press releases, and it has always been amusing. However, this one, with its misleading and extravagant claims, will severely dent his future credibility. Inevitably in his shadow portfolio position he will find some real flaws in the electoral system and no-one will believe him because he has cried wolf once too often.

ANSWER.PARA: To begin, I pose the following question: Why did Senator Short not speak to the Electoral Commissioner before going off half-cocked? Senator Short would know that at any time he can ring the Electoral Commissioner and discuss electoral matters with him. He did not ring the Commissioner because he knew in his heart of hearts that such a phone call would deflate and expose his naive conspiracy theories. I have a letter from the Electoral Commissioner to Senator Short that went with the circular. It invited Senator Short to ring the Commissioner and discuss the matter. If Senator Short had done so, he would have received an explanation that would have satisfied him and he would not have gone off and told his Leader, Mr Howard, about this exciting discovery, with the result that Mr Howard went off half-briefed last night in Albury. All those things could have been avoided.

What are the facts? The Electoral Commission has authorised a recheck of statistical returns in six sample divisions. The intention of the check is to correct any sloppy bookkeeping. I stress that point. What we are talking about is not a miscount of votes, in the main, but sloppy bookkeeping; that is, a failure to meet the bookkeeping requirements of the operations manual that is sent out by the Electoral Commission. If the honourable senator cannot understand that difference he should move six feet back out of his seat and on to the back bench.

Since Federation, there have been minor statistical errors in the keeping of records in this area, under both Liberal and Labor governments. But two things changed after 1983. Firstly, the accuracy of electoral figures became an absolutely essential part of public funding. Accurate figures in terms of public funding are required because every vote for a party that achieves more than 4 per cent of the vote is paid for from public funding. Secondly, after the 1983 election, we required a recheck of every ballot paper in Australia. That had never been done before. We did it because of the desire of politicians, journalists and academics to achieve a true two-party preferred vote in the result sheets of the voting system. Prior to 1983, unless preferences had been allocated in a particular electorate, it was all Mackerras-type guesswork and we did not have an accurate two-party preferred vote. For those two reasons it has been necessary to lift the standard of the requirement on divisional returning officers to provide their relevant information accurately and without any errors whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have mathematical errors. The Commissioner says there are mathematical errors.

—Why does Senator Walters not listen and learn something, instead of babbling on? Let me use an example from 1984 to clarify this matter, an example that probably no-one on the other side has bothered to read about. In 1984, adjustments were made to the amount paid to each political party under public funding provisions. The adjustments followed the finalisation of election results and were reported in the AEC interim report on funding disclosures, in September 1985, some nine months after the 1984 election. The largest adjustment was the recovery of $99.75 from the Australian Labor Party (ALP) in Queensland and the second largest was the payment of $52.02 to the Liberal Party in the Australian Capital Territory. The implication is that for the whole State of Queensland, after checking all the divisions, approximately 120 votes-$100-were found not to be in the right piles or correctly allocated. That is the dimension of the problem Mr Hughes has been referring to-not that the 1987 election result could be in any doubt. The magnitude of corrections to the final statistical returns, obviously, is extremely small. There is no chance that any result could be affected. The closest results last year were for Fisher, 703 votes, held by the ALP; and Chisholm, 872 votes, won by the Liberals. The magnitude of the error not only is nowhere near this, it is barely into double figures.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me move to what I would have thought to be the more important part of Senator Short's question-not the sloppy bookkeeping by divisional returning officers in their eventual returns to the Electoral Commissioner. What would worry me more is the reference to the disenfranchisement of voters. I see Senator Short nodding. We agree on this. If any voters in this country are disenfranchised, if their votes are not correctly counted, that is a major area for concern. Those concerns came up very clearly in the first Nunawading election, when the matter went to a court of disputed returns, and the Government subsequently amended a whole variety of sections of the Electoral Act to cover such contingencies. I might add that there was a concern in 1984, when certain overseas absentee votes from the United States did not arrive in Australia because the consular officials and so on did not obey the Electoral Commission's directive to send the votes back by courier. They were put in diplomatic bags and disappeared. Subsequently, we amended the Electoral Act to give the Electoral Commissioner power to direct consular officials and to fine and discipline them if they fail to respond.

What are the facts in the 1987 election? How many votes went missing? There was one case of votes going missing, which is not a bad record compared with other times and other cases in courts of disputed returns. There was one case where 182 votes were improperly transferred, or failed to be transferred, to the Lalor electorate. What we have set up for absentee votes is a central clearing house. All absentee votes go to the clearing house and are then returned to each electorate. One officer of the Electoral Commission, in one division, failed to uphold his duty in that regard. If that had happened for a seat in which the result differed by 200 votes, no doubt the matter would have gone to the Court of Disputed Returns and there would have been gross embarrassment all around. It is not something we endorse. I think even Senator Short would concede that even though we were highly indignant at the absence of those 182 votes that went to the Labor electorate-and most of them were Labor votes, so we are down in funding, I might add-they barely made a difference. Barry Jones's majority in Lalor was $25,000-or, I should say, 25,000 votes. I might add that that is the last electorate in Australia on which we are likely to spend $25,000. If one can get more than $100 out of Barry Jones one is going well.

I come to another part of Senator Short's question. I am sorry I have taken so long to give the answer, but he has criticised me for not making a statement in this Parliament on this matter and he deserves a full and honest response. I would not deny that the wording employed in that circular by the Electoral Commissioner was overblown. I understand that the intention was to impress individual divisional staff of the importance placed on accuracy by the Electoral Commissioner and, indeed, this Parliament. It was basically to give them a touch-up and to make sure that no sloppiness existed.

I say while I am on that subject that, even where there has been sloppy bookkeeping in this regard, our Electoral Commission still has the highest level of integrity of any such body in the world. Even at its sloppiest, it still has the best standard in the world in terms of recording votes. I am sure that the Electoral Commissioner-I have talked to him today-regrets the overemphasis in the circular on those matters. There is, of course, some irony in that he was demonstrating his keenness to provide Senator Short with answers to his request for statistical information on these matters. I presume that when the copy of this information was sent to Senator Short he also read the covering note of invitation.

I wish to say two other things. We have already seen this week an example of the Liberal Party jumping the gun by way of Press release, trying to distort matters. We had the case of Senator Chaney on Monday night saying in regard to the Robert Wood matter that the Labor Party had amended the Commonwealth Electoral Act and had been caught out. Subsequent research showed that it was the Liberal Party which amended the Act, and inserted those provisions. Senator Chaney has not even had the decency to apologise for that blunder.

In my former occupation as a teacher I had to deal with a whole lot of recalcitrant students in class 3F in a technical school. In most cases, with some perseverance, I was able to succeed. In trying to educate Senator Short in these matters, however, I face the most herculean task of my career. But I am going to persist. Every time he puts out an inaccurate, basically stupid and misleading Press release, I will respond, I will nail it down. I think he owes the journalists of this country an apology for putting out these sorts of furphies, these sorts of interpretations, which have caused some who did not check to run ridiculous articles associated with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. We have just heard an almost 15-minute blustering and totally irrelevant diatribe from the Minister. He has not answered one of the questions I put to him. I repeat: I want to know how the Minister can explain the yawning chasm between his description and the comments of the Electoral Commissioner. The Electoral Commissioner himself says that there are a number of substantial defects and that it now appears possible that the existing returns and statistics of the 1987 election cannot be relied upon with any certainty. I want to know how the Minister reconciles that with his description of `possible minor inadequacies at the local level'. I ask again: Will he give a full statement to the Senate about the facts of this matter instead of going on with an irrelevant, blustering diatribe?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I am going to do when I leave this chamber is get the phone number of the Electoral Commissioner and provide it to Senator Short. If he had bothered, if he had just taken the time yesterday, to ring the Commissioner, that explanation would have been given.
—It is your responsibility. You are the Minister.

—Yes; I take full responsibility. We have an independent Electoral Commission, as I have made clear on many occasions. I do not run away, though, from responsibility for the Electoral Commission. I could do so. I could hide behind the fact that it is an independent Commission and has nothing to do with me. I do not. I seek to defend the Commission because in this case it certainly deserves defence. Senator Short has quoted the Commissioner as having said that the election results cannot be relied upon with any degree of accuracy. The Commissioner was saying that, on his own view and by his own standards, if the return says that 333,330 people voted Labor when, in fact, 333,329 voted Labor, that figure cannot be relied on as accurate.

ANSWER.PARA: We are not talking in terms of large discrepancies. What we are basically talking about, which Senator Short has failed to grasp, is the difference between the counting and recording of votes and the sloppy bookkeeping in returning those figures to the Electoral Commission. That is the nub of it. I ask Senator Short to see whether he can focus for just one minute on the difference between the actual counting of the votes and the declaration of a poll and then when it comes to reconcile misused ballot papers, destroyed ballot papers, et cetera, whether in the transference of that count to the bookkeeping returning officers have been sloppy. They have been. They should not be. They should follow the manual.

Senator Short has an opportunity to explore this matter. If he talks to the Electoral Commissioner today, as I invite him to do-I will have the Electoral Commissioner come to see him-and the Commissioner can convince the honourable senator, as I am sure he will, that no election result was in doubt following all this-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought he was independent.

—The Electoral Commission is one of the finest examples of open government co-operation with political parties in this country. It responds to all political inquiries, no matter which parties they come from, and it is a credit to it that it does. Senator Chaney is trying to divert me. Let me respond to Senator Short. If, after a conversation with Professor Hughes, he can be convinced that no election result was in doubt, we can then move on. We are doing a sample of six electorates to try to measure accurately where this sloppiness is. That, in turn, will be reported to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, of which Senator Short is a member. He will have the opportunity to cross-examine and to discuss these matters. The whole difficulty, which Senator Short fails to understand, is that we are not talking in magnitudes of hundreds of thousands of votes; we are talking in the magnitude of a few votes. Inaccuracies have existed since Federation. We are talking about the higher standards now required of divisional returning officers than have existed before.

ANSWER.PARA: I make a final point. Some consideration has been given to regionalisation of electoral offices to avoid these mistakes. I have been a bit reluctant to support that proposal because of the unusual electoral configurations and the artificiality involved. But this is certainly one example of excuses given by divisional returning officers for their alleged sloppiness which could be met by regionalisation-another thing which Senator Short and others on the Committee will progress.

I invite Senator Short to discuss this matter with Dr Colin Hughes to see whether any electorate would have any different result concerning his staff circular. If the honourable senator is convinced after that, I will then invite him to put out another Press release, this time based on fact, on reality and on honest judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It relates to the matter of takeover bids for listed public companies. Will the Minister explain to the Senate the nature of the benefits which economists regard the takeover mechanism as providing for the economy as a whole? Are there recent examples of company takeovers which provide evidence of this process in action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President--
—Fancy your first question being a dorothy dixer.

—The honourable senator should wait until she hears the answer. The orthodox theory behind company takeovers is that if a company has a moribund or incompetent set of managers and directors who are inefficiently utilising the company's assets, it will be subjected to the discipline of the market-place, that is a bid for takeover so that the moribund and incompetent managers and directors will be replaced by a more entrepreneurial and competent set of managers and directors. I notice that Senator Stone is nodding his head as I expect he would do because that is the orthodox theory. It is based on the idea that those mounting the takeover bid, having assumed that under their superior management the earnings of the company will increase, can afford to pay more for the target company shares than the prevailing market price and by paying more thereby indu-cing the existing shareholders into selling their shares at the above market price.

ANSWER.PARA: There is one recent example of a takeover which is particularly interesting when viewed against that background. I refer to the takeover of Peko-Wallsend Ltd by North Broken Hill Holdings Ltd. I understand that although this takeover is not formally completed, North Broken Hill had acquired 90 per cent of the shareholding in Peko by yesterday and has extended the time period to give the remaining 10 per cent of shareholders the opportunity to sell if they wish. Therefore, the bid can be regarded as successful. Whether the takeover of Peko should be attributed to its past management and to the three years or whatever it was that Senator Stone spent on the board as a director and the many years that Mr Copeman has been--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 15 months. Get your facts right.

—Fifteen months. For many years Mr Copeman has been the Chief Executive as well as a director during which period he took the opportunity to use Peko as a social and industrial laboratory for the New Right. Whether the influence of that management unduly depressed the earnings of Peko and therefore prompted the takeover bid or, alternatively, whether the Peko takeover should be seen as what is known as a friendly takeover which, by definition, is incompatible with the orthodox theory, is a matter on which I do not propose to pronounce judgment.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to the 1 February edition of the Syntec publication Business Outlook? Does the bar chart titled `Australia's increasing burden', which appears on page 10 of the publication, give a reasonable or a misleading picture of Australia's debt servicing burden?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the Syntec newsletter Business Outlook and I have a copy here. A bar graph in that publication which purports to show Australia's foreign debt problem is misleading. Although it is based on Reserve Bank of Australia data, the method of presentation is highly misleading and I am surprised that a Syntec publication would have presented it in that form. But the graph, having been presented in that form by Syntec, has been taken up by a number of other publications. I understand that there is an impending staff addition in Syntec as a result of which I trust the method of presentation of data will be improved. But only time can show that.

ANSWER.PARA: The bar graph to which I refer is headed `gross debt servicing to exports' and purports to show that debt servicing is currently consuming about two-thirds of our total export returns. Before I proceed further let me acknowledge, in case Senator Stone subsequently accuses me of not doing so, that Australia does have a foreign debt problem. But the appreciation of that foreign debt problem and the remedying of it is not assisted by presentations which are as misleading as is the Syntec bar graph presentation. It is misleading for this reason: the figure of 64.2 per cent, to be precise, designated as gross debt servicing to exports-that is 64.2 per cent of exports consumed by gross debt servicing-relates to all interest payments paid outwards from Australia during the last financial year plus all the repayments of principal that were paid out. In other words, there is an ongoing servicing component and a capital component.

The degree to which that presentation is so misleading as to be almost meaningless can be shown by this comparison: let us assume that all foreign debt was for a term of 12 months. By definition all of the principal would have to be repaid or rolled over within that 12 months. If that were the case, the ratio of gross debt servicing to exports would not be 64 per cent but 250 per cent. The underlying reality would not have changed. The far more relevant figure is, of course, the interest cost of servicing the debt which, in the case that I have cited and to which Syntec refers, is 20 per cent and not 64.2 per cent. It is correct, as I mentioned earlier, that the Syntec graph was derived from a Reserve Bank table. Immediately adjacent to the column which showed the figures on which the table was based in the Reserve Bank publication was the interest servicing cost which was shown at 20 per cent. To take one figure out without adequately qualifying it is highly misleading. It does not really tell us much about the underlying position.

One other qualification is that 1986-87 was the first year in which the Reserve Bank included in that table repayments of principal by banks. The Reserve Bank explicitly noted that the series should not be taken as being continuous for that reason. There had been a very substantive change relating to banks when, of course, it is the business of banks to be raising and repaying deposits all the time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the Torres Strait treaty between Australia and Papua New Guinea, traditional visits are allowed by adjacent PNG residents into a defined area of the Torres Strait without formal passport and visa documentation.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —So honourable senators opposite are not interested. I would have thought that they would have great interest in finding out what the Government's view of this criticism is. This legal movement is regularly misrepresented as illegal immigration. ANSWER.PARA: To improve the efficiency of the monitoring a new system has been developed for progressive introduction on islands in the Strait. The Opposition would have brought this matter of public importance forward for debate in any event, but our desire and our belief that it is necessary to do so is heightened by the fact that we have already seen, through two delays in the completion of the police investigations, that this is a matter which is increasingly showing all the signs of a matter of major moment.
