It goes to the question of the whole integrity of government. It has potentially the gravest constitutional and political consequences. We saw this last year in my own State of Victoria with the corruption by the Australian Labor Party in the Nunawading how-to-vote card scandal. We have seen this corruption and debasing of the political capital of this country pursued without relief in New South Wales under the Wran-Unsworth governments during the past decade, a decade of unrivalled corruption and abuse of power by senior public officials in that State. My colleagues Senator Michael Baume and Senator Bishop will be going into that example of that situation of corruption and abuse in their State in much greater detail when they follow me in this debate. We have to recall the conviction and gaoling of Police Minister Rex Jackson, for accepting bribes, and former Chief Stipendiary Magistrate Murray Farquhar, for attempting to pervert the course of justice; and there are many more examples.

The Opposition's wording calls for the public release of the report by the Australian Federal Police. In putting that forward, I insert two caveats. The first is that, without knowledge at this stage of the content of that report and the consequences that might flow from it, there may obviously be need for some delay in the timing of its release for legal or other purposes. There also may be need to have some deletions made to the report when it is made public in order to protect innocent parties who may be named in it. I make it clear at the outset that the Opposition fully accepts these caveats.

The Opposition believes that this is a vital matter because it goes to the heart of the political process; it goes to the need to protect political propriety, integrity and morality in this country. The case of the Labor Party's handling of the $10,000 donation from the woodchip company Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd to its election campaign coffers in 1987 goes to the heart of these fundamental issues and threatens to debase them beyond repeal. It has been shown by many political researchers that the whole process of parliament and of government in this country is very importantly related to the attitude of the community to the morality of those who engage in politics. Whilst the report of the police is not yet available the indications are, I believe, that those are issues that are very much involved here.

Let us look at the facts of this case. It first came to light at the end of January when the New South Wales Minister responsible for the environment, Mr Carr, in what was thought to be a cheap political trick, accused the Liberal Party of receiving funds in the last election campaign from the woodchip company Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd for its election campaign purposes. It was quite correct that the Liberal Party had received those funds, and they were disclosed in the proper and normal way, so there was no secret about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is how he knew.

—Yes, that is how he knew. Mr Carr claimed that the Labor Party was a clean skin on it in the sense that it had not received money from this company which was at great odds with his constituencies, the greenies and the conservationists in New South Wales, who were not only making very loud noises but-and this is very important-were financially supporting the Labor Government in that election campaign. What Mr Carr apparently did not know at the time was that the Labor Party had received a similar cheque for the same purpose from the company, Harris-Daishowa. On 11 June 1987 Harris-Daishowa wrote to Mr Young, the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party and a senior Minister in the Government, saying that the company had had no hesitation in helping with the cost of campaigns over long periods and helping candidates of all political parties, and enclosing a cheque for $10,000. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: We have pleasure in enclosing a cheque in support of the Labor Party's election campaign and we would respectfully suggest that this be directed to the Eden-Monaro promotion campaign account.

In other words, the company specifically requested that that money, in line with its previous contributions on earlier elections, be publicly disclosed, because election campaign donations have to be. Two weeks later, on 24 June, Mr Loosley, the Secretary of the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party wrote back to the company saying that Mr Young had forwarded the donation to him `to assist in the New South Wales branch of the ALP in its administration'. Because of that the donation was not disclosed. Following Mr Carr's remarks at the end of January 1988, Harris-Daishowa raised this issue, and that is how the whole matter was made public. Harris-Daishowa, in its letter of 2 February, objected to what had happened and specifically said:
Harris-Daishowa . . . emphatically deny releasing any letter which is being used in an attempt to promote a campaign fund controversy.
This raises a very important question that I presume the Federal Police will look at-that is, if the company did not leak that letter to the media, who did?

On 2 February, when this matter first came to light, the New South Wales Secretary of the Labor Party, Mr Loosley, when asked why this situation had arisen and why the money had gone into the administration account rather than the campaign funds, was quoted in the Press as saying that he `understood from a conversation with Mr Young at the time'-that is, in June 1987-`that the money should go into the administration account'. On the same day, Mr Young, who was, of course, a senior Minister of the Government and the Federal President of the Labor Party, as he still is, said that he did not recall ever seeing the covering letter, nor could he remember handing over the cheque to Mr Loosley. What a comment that is. How could a senior Minister of the Crown, a man who had been the State Secretary of the Labor Party in South Australia for five years and who had followed that with five years as National Secretary of the Labor Party-so he had 10 years as a senior Labor Party official, concerned with the handling of funds for election campaign purposes and the administration of his Party-not remember receiving either a letter or a cheque for that amount?

TALK.START.PARA: —And a first class bagman to boot.
—Yes, I agree with Senator MacGibbon. On 2 February Mr Young said:

SPEECH.PARA: No-one can give a proper explanation for what has occurred. But obviously it is a fairly honest mistake.

It is not obvious to me. It is not obvious that it was honest-even fairly honest-nor is it obvious that it was a mistake. There appears to be a much better argument that it was a fairly dirty trick. Indeed, on 2 February, the day that all this broke, Mr Loosley rang 2GB in Sydney to say that it was his understanding that the money had been intended by the company for the Party's maintenance and administration account. He said, after having referred to thinking back during that period of the year, that he understood from a conversation with Mr Young at the time that the administration account was the account to which the donation should have been paid, and they acted accordingly.

When Mr Young was asked about that on 2 February, he said that he had `no reason to argue' with Mr Loosley's recollection. Two days later-48 hours later-hey-presto! All is well. The letter which had been missing for all this time was found in Mr Loosley's office in Sydney. `Mr Young's cleared', says the Labor Party, `of any wrongdoing'. The Press cleared him, too. It was all Mr Loosley's fault. He had not found that letter when he should have found it. He had not remembered that he got that letter back in June 1987. Indeed, he had remembered that he had a conversation with Mr Young about where the money was to go, and that was all'. As Michelle Grattan said in the Age at the time: `It was a wonderful case of laying the blame Loosley speaking'.
Within two days Mr Loosley changed his earlier recollection of the 1987 discussion with Mr Young. Indeed, so much did he change it that he said:
Given that the Harris-Daishowa correspondence is here in our office, it is not possible that that conversation could have related to that contribution.
Asked who might then have given him the impression that the money was for the administration accounts, Mr Loosley said:
That is something that continues to elude us, frankly.

The letter may have turned up in Mr Loosley's office, but not the fact, nor, as I believe would be obvious to blind Freddy, the truth. Mr Loosley's statements are riddled with contradictions. His confession did not change in any way the fact that the Labor Party deliberately attempted to circumvent the provisions of the Electoral Act by redirecting a donation specifically targeted by Harris-Daishowa to the Eden-Monaro promotion campaign account and diverted that to the Labor Party's administration account. Nor was the basic issue in any way lessened-and that is the debasing of those very precious commodities of political integrity, political propriety and morality in this country. They have not in any way been lessened by the discovery of the letter in Mr Loosley's files, nor were they in any way lessened by Mr Young's resignation four days later.

The questions that have been asked by the Opposition and by others from the outset of this tawdry affair, this scandal, remain-questions such as how and when Harris-Daishowa's letter to Mr Young of 11 June 1987 and the accompanying cheque were transmitted from Mr Young to Mr Loosley; and whether Mr Loosley received both the cheque and the letter at the same time. I asked Senator Robert Ray, the Minister for Home Affairs, a question on that matter the other day in this chamber. He said that it did not really matter because it was not relevant. I think I quote him correctly. He said that it was not pertinent to the case. I submit to the Minister that it is of the most vital importance.

What is the explanation for Mr Loosley's initial statement that he had had a conversation with Mr Young in June 1987 about what to do with the $10,000? How could it happen that Mr Young could not remember receiving either the letter or the cheque from Harris-Daishowa despite Mr Loosley's statement that he had, that he and Mr Young had discussed the cheque? What were the reasons for Mr Loosley dramatically altering his story in the space of 48 hours? If Mr Loosley received the Harris-Daishowa letter and cheque from Mr Young at the same time, how on earth could he have written to the company on 24 June saying that the $10,000 would assist the New South Wales branch of the ALP in its administrations, when the company's letter of 11 June had expressly stated that the cheque was `in support of the Labor Party's election campaign' and `We would respectfully suggest that this be directed to the Eden-Monaro promotion account'? How did the company's letter of 11 June come to be found, according to Mr Loosley, in a `file of national ALP papers' on 4 February 1988, bearing in mind that Mr Loosley is the New South Wales Secretary of the Party? What annotations were on the letter when it was found? Was a copy of Mr Loosley's letter of 24 June, acknowledging the money in writing to Harris-Daishowa, attached in that file? What is the name of the file? Where is it kept? Who had had access to it in the days preceding the sudden miraculous discovery of the letter? All those basic questions have been asked but not answered. Presumably the police report will cover them.

The thing that has interested me, and many others I am sure-not only in politics but outside-is this: Why would Mr Young resign and why would he do so at such a critical time? He resigned two days after the Adelaide by-election, a disastrous by-election result for his Party, and in an adjoining seat to his own when he knew that his resignation would bring about another by-election. He knows that the New South Wales election is six or eight weeks away. He is the national President of the Party. Mr Young's whole Party generally is reeling on the political ropes and he resigns at that time.

After all, he had survived-that is perhaps the right word-much more in the past than this episode. He had survived the Combe-Ivanov affair when he had been named by a royal commissioner as having breached Australia's security. He had survived the Paddington bear affair when he had falsely signed a Customs declaration. And he resigned after the media-his court-had cleared him a couple of days earlier. Still he resigned. The only reason he gave was `media overkill'. Quite frankly, that is simply unbelievable. Mr Young knew that his resignation would be a body blow to the Hawke Government and a body blow to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) because they were the closest of mates according to the Prime Minister and Mr Young.

I believe various reasons need to be looked at as to why Mr Young resigned. This is one of the essential reasons why the police report must be completed and made available. Until it is, these matters will remain in the realm of speculation. Let us name of couple of these matters. There was a very interesting article in the Melbourne Sun on 9 February by Dennis Atkins, who was the Press Secretary to Mr Young in the period 1983-1985. Mr Atkins pointed out that Mr Young had been loyal to the end to the nation. I do not disagree, because Mr Young normally would be loyal to the end to his Party. Atkins said, quite rightly:

Mick Young was someone who dedicated his life to the politics of the Left, first in the trade union movement then the party machine and until the middle of yesterday afternoon, the parliamentary process.

He talked about loyalty and said that Mr Young left because of his loyalty to the Party. On the other hand, in yesterday's Melbourne Age there was a very interesting comment by Ken Davidson. He said of Mr Young that what finally precipitated him to go was what he saw:

. . . as the lack of party support, not even a telephone call, between the time the issue surfaced publicly and the belated discovery of the Harris-Daishowa letter in the NSW Labor Party headquarters.

He points out that the disclosure of the Harris-Daishowa gift was a real bonus to the New South Wales Right in the battle that is looming over the Deputy Prime Ministership when Lionel Bowen goes. It would have been between Keating and Young. Young is now eliminated. A very good question is: Why did Bob Carr let the whole thing originate?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance, in the terms in which it is written, is quite misleading. It refers to `breaches' of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Anyone with any decency would have put `alleged breaches'. However, I am somewhat restricted in dealing with some of the material that Senator Short has produced. We are awaiting the police report. I also leave it to my colleague, Senator Tate, to address the more technical question in this matter of public importance as to the efficacy of releasing a police report. I add that at this stage no decision has been made by the Government one way or the other. How could we until we see a report?
—We may not even see it.
—As my colleague points out, as Government Ministers we may never see it. I quote what I said to the Senate in November 1983 with regard to disclosure:

SPEECH.PARA: There will always be a way round-
disclosure-
but what the legislation does is to set down at least what the moral principles are in politics and if people want to break them they can take the consequences.

In recent weeks I have made that point far more explicitly. I have said that, no matter which political party someone belongs to, if there is a breach of the Electoral Act the person responsible should be prosecuted. I am not assuming anything in this case until the evidence comes in. We on this side of the House and the Government will not back away from the enforcement of the Electoral Act, now or later. I notice that the new member for Adelaide, Mr Pratt, is asking us not to enforce the Electoral Act in terms of not fining people who did not vote. That is another recent example of someone who would like us to ignore the Electoral Act. Again, it is not for us to interfere.

I have listened on many occasions in this chamber to speeches from Liberals. I have listened to the phony ethics of those opposite about donations. They say that Liberal politicians never see the money, that they never have anything to do with it; therefore, there is no need at all for disclosure. I have heard that statement made time and time again. I refer the Senate to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 27 August 1981:
The Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, has been warned by major manufacturing interests who are vital Liberal Party donors that their funds would be withdrawn if the Federal Government cuts tariffs.
One Liberal Party source told the Herald that the interests involved were six-figure donors to the Party and come from the backbone of the Party's financial base.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was seven years ago.
—I will move through these matters in chronological order for Senator Teague. The Sydney Morning Herald, in a profile of Peter Nixon on 12 September 1981, wrote the following:

SPEECH.PARA: A Liberal Minister who canvassed funds in Melbourne before the 1977 election found that Nixon had beaten him to most of the likely contributors. `He didn't leave anything for the Liberal Party,' the minister laments.

On 15 September another revealing article appeared in the Australian about a Mr Gale, who was a great friend of Mr Fraser, although I do not think Mr Fraser visited him in prison once during the eight or nine years he had to spend there after the friendship ended. Gale swapped cheques for $25,000 with a Japanese businessman to get a clean donation to the Liberal Party. He said:
it would be better to have a cheque from a foreigner.
Let us go to a Liberal Party source that is more impeccable, with a direct quote from Mr Leo Hawkins, former State Director of the Victorian Liberal Party. On Nationwide he said:

Now, I think it is quite wrong for the Prime Minister, the Premier and other leaders to have to go through the sorts of antics that are required to lever money out of people in the community who have got relatively large sums to give.
The reality is that the Liberal Party has been consistent on one aspect.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the $1,000 breakfasts your leader gives? What a hypocrite. He gives $1,000 breakfasts.
—I did not interrupt Senator Short once during his speech-not once.
—He was not talking such nonsense, and he was quoting.
—Order! Senator Baume, I notice that you are on the speakers list for a later time.

—Senator Baume might get a response then. The Liberal and National parties have at least been consistent. They opposed disclosure from day one and they oppose it today. On that they have been absolutely consistent. On the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform they fought tooth and nail to prevent the introduction into the Commonwealth Electoral Act of any disclosure laws. In this and the other chamber they fought tooth and nail to stop any disclosure. As well as that, they opposed public funding. On a matter of principle they would not touch funding-but they all took the money. That describes the principles of those opposite. They oppose public funding, yet they take the money. I remember seeing a definition of that somewhere. It had something to do with prostitution.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the attitude of the Liberal Party now that we have disclosure laws. Let us take New South Wales. That is what this is about. There were disclosure laws in New South Wales at the time of the 1984 State election. At the last New South Wales elections the Liberal Party managed to siphon off $3.9m through Canberra to cover the sources of its dirty money. What did Mr Valder have to say about it? He stated:
We are hoping to send a great deal of money out of the State, and to bring it back to avoid disclosing the identity of the donors.
That is what Mr Valder said. He said:
It is not flouting the law, it is protecting a great principle of confidentiality in this country.

Those opposite accuse people of trying to hide the disclosure of donations. An amount of $3.9m in the 1984 State election in New South Wales was sent out of New South Wales to Robert Menzies' house here and then sent back as a donation. So not one cent of it could be declared under the New South Wales Electoral Act. Let us go to Queensland and Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. In an article in the Daily Mirror he stated-Senator Teague has gone, but we are at least up to 30 April 1987:
. . . the Electoral Act amendments requiring parties to disclose the organisations which have donated had been made to stop him getting to the top in Canberra.

In other words, we amended the Act in 1983 in anticipation that he would make the run for Canberra in 1987, but leaving aside the stupidity of that he went on to describe it as `a devilish piece of legislation aimed at me'. So the Queensland National Party has always opposed donations. Of course, his State President, his one-time mentor and campaign director but later fallen out friend Sir Robert Sparkes, in the National Times in March 1987, had the following to say:
You don't have to take any notice of the disclosure laws, give us as much money as you can.

He then made promises. When the Nationals swept to power in Canberra in 1987, he said, `We will retrospectively amend the law', in spite of the fact that in this chamber every national gets up here and says, `We will never support retrospectivity'. So members of the National Party were able to repeal their greatest and strongest principle when it came to disclosure; that is that they would repeal retrospectively the disclosure laws of this country.

We have all known for a number of years about the power and influence and absolute rottenness of the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation. The only historical equivalent that I can discover for it is a Huey Long machine in Louisiana in the 1930s. People who need government contracts are pressured into donating to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation. There are people from Senator Parer's party, such as Mr Litchfield, who have gone on record publicly and said that people have come to the Liberal Party of Queensland to say that they were pressured to give money to the National Party. Not one person opposite has ever got up and admitted, debated or shown any concern about that. The last words of that great film on Huey Long had him dying in the hospital bed with everyone round saying, `Huey, Huey, where is the deduct box?'. A similar situation exists in Queensland. The day Sir Joh went out of office I can imagine all the Nationals running in to him and saying, `Joh, Joh, where is the deduct box?'. How much do we cream off the top of the National Party there? One would expect that if the Liberal Party is making the running on disclosure, it would be concerned about loopholes and about changes, but it has expressed no such concern. Let us take John Elliott, Federal President of the Liberal Party. On 5 February he stated:
We didn't make these stupid laws about disclosure of funds.
And we believe that political parties ought to be funded by private donations, they ought to be kept confidential and there should be no need to disclose. They (the ALP) never had a system to do it.
The Liberal Party have always had a better system to handle it.

So the titular head of a Liberal Party at an organisational level, Mr John Elliott, does not want disclosure laws. During the lead-up to the Adelaide by-election Mr Howard made a whole series of comments about the disclosure laws. He offered to open up his Party funds to spot audits, but then later retracted that. He mentioned that maybe the Party's administrative and maintenance fund should be opened up. But what did he have to say after the Adelaide by-election? He did a doorstop interview on Tuesday, 16 February. He was asked by a reporter:
Will you be calling for any changes in the electoral law?
Mr Howard's answer was:
Not at this stage, no.

It is quite obvious, and we have said so throughout, that disclosure laws and the legislation as it exists at the current time is not perfect. Liberal representatives on the Electoral Reform Committee have said it, I have said it and I am sure that Senator Macklin as a long-standing member of the Committee has said it too. However, there was one major loophole discovered after the 1984 election: a donation to one organisation which then forwarded the money on in its own name-what we call third party donations. It was a disguised way of getting around the disclosure laws. For anyone who wants to check the bona fides of this Government with regard to that, the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform recommended that this loophole be closed off. Most people know that, before the 1987 election, some fast track legislation was introduced embodying only a few of the recommendations of the Electoral Reform Committee. Probably about 15 out of 120-odd were picked up in that emergency legislation. Included in that were amendments to the Act to cut out these third party donations. Having put that Bill through-it was debated in this chamber after the election was announced-we proclaimed it within about a day of its passage. If this Government were weak on its bona fides regarding disclosure, that legislation containing those provisions would never have been proclaimed in that period.

Let us never forget some of the hypocrisy that we are hearing from the Liberal and National parties on disclosure. They have never wanted disclosure laws. But now that there is an alleged breach of the disclosure laws they want a full prosecution, having already given the verdict. It is a little like Alice in Wonderland. Senator Short and his colleagues come out, like the Queen of Hearts, and say, `Guilty'. They almost give the sentence first, then the verdict, and then they will hear the evidence. That is not the order in which we work in our society. Let us wait until the evidence. If there is evidence available, prosecutions are launched under the Electoral Act.

It is also very much the case of the dog that did not bark. Senator Short, on this and other matters, invites us to make some sort of comment on breaches of the Electoral Act. I now throw the invitation his way. Apart from this issue, I have not heard Senator Short comment on convictions under the Electoral Act. Let me remind Senator Short of three convictions. He might be able to correct me about whether he issued a comment on these cases. On 9 February 1988 National Party scrutineer Mr Wah Day was fined $300 in a Cairns magistrates court for attempting to fill out a ballot paper he found outside a polling booth on 11 July last year. This individual was convicted of ballot rorting. He was a National Party person. I did not comment on this case until it went through the full procedures and went to the magistrate court. I knew of an impending prosecution and I could have said in here that he was obviously guilty-another National Party rorter caught. I did not.

I now mention a second case. Did Senator Short or anyone on the other side of this chamber mention this blatant breach of the Electoral Act, or put out a Press release to congratulate the Electoral Commission for bringing a felon to book for his crimes? No, they did not. There was dead and absolute silence. The second case was on 23 November 1987. It involved a National Party MLA in Queensland. Mr Dennis Hinton was fined $400 in the Brisbane magistrates court for forging a false signature on a joint Commonwealth-Queensland enrolment card. He later used parliamentary privilege, of course, to attack the officers of the Electoral Commission and the Australian Federal Police for carrying out their duty. Here we have an official member of the National Party, a member of the State Parliament, bodgying enrolment cards and being convicted in the court. Did Opposition senators here once mention the case, once congratulate the Electoral Commission for pursuing offenders under the Electoral Act? Did they say nothing? Yes, they said nothing. Why did they say nothing? Because they never criticise their own. That is their internal rule.

A third case was brought to the attention of this Senate by Senator Black last year. But it was never once commented on by the Opposition. It was about the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct and Allegations-and I stress they were only allegations at this point-that Mr Don Lane had been responsible for putting bodgies on the electoral roll. That was the accusation that was made. The inquiry from our side of the House was: Is there any truth to this? Will it be investigated? And so on. The Opposition was absolutely silent on this matter. What constrains the Opposition to chase one breach of the Electoral Act and no others? This one was not pursued. I thought that even the Liberal Party might have pursued it because Mr Don Lane used to be a member of that party until he ratted to the National Party of Queensland on the basis of an offer of a ministry. That is not unparliamentary. Everyone knows that that is true.

In all those cases of breaches of the Electoral Act, no mention comes from the Opposition. We have a major investigation going at the moment-I hope that my colleague from the Northern Territory will get time to allude to it-into a front organisation pouring a massive amount of money into the Queensland National Party. I will not comment on whether it is guilty or not. I have not even commented on the investigation. I could have come in here and made great play of all the Northern Territory people involved in that, but I did not do so. The matter is under investigation. If there are breaches those Liberal Party-National Party members in Queensland will be prosecuted like anyone else under the Act.

The matter of public importance before us is poorly based. It says `breaches of the Commonwealth Electoral Act'. It should say `alleged breaches of the Commonwealth Electoral Act'. If honourable senators really want to know what the matter of public importance is today, it is this: `We hereby want to think up an excuse to get involved in the New South Wales election. We are looking for a device to do so and this is the device by which we will do it'. Senator Short will be given the job of running through all the alleged facts of the case that he sees, pre-judging all the way through and barely mentioning the subject matter to which this matter of public importance is restricted, which will at least take the shine off the new ball, so the two apparatchiks from the New South Wales Liberal Party-Senator Peter Baume and Senator Bishop-can go back into the mud box and start throwing mud around as they did in the discussion of a matter of public importance on Wednesday and fairly poorly last night.

That is what this is about. It is an insult to the Electoral Act, the Electoral Commission and everyone who serves it. They are simply using this issue for the tawdry purpose of trying to make some pathetic points about the New South Wales State election. To do so, they are willing to abrogate every legal principle in the book to allege that Mr Young or Mr Loosley is guilty and so on. They come into this place, make those allegations and demand that the police report, which they and I have had no access to, be made available.

I continue to support disclosure laws in the Federal Parliament. I will continue to support them as they exist in New South Wales. I will continue, wherever I go in Australia, to motivate the other four State governments, be they Labor, Liberal or National, to introduce disclosure legislation, because it is a major protection against having political parties obligated to anything else. It is important that political parties are not dependent on financing from private individuals who will obligate them. In part, public funding helps ameliorate that. In part, disclosure helps ameliorate that position. If there are loopholes in the Act and the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters recommends that those loopholes be closed-not that there is a loophole in the case discussed by Senator Short-I will be more than happy to do so. If one wants to take a principled stand one must follow it through all the way. I invite, but I do not expect, support from the Liberal and National parties on this issue. We will get the same reaction as we have had for the last five years-that of dragging the chain and not supporting any change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last few days there have been discussions in the media about whether this Parliament should be broadcast and whether the Australian Broadcasting Corporation should lose so much time on one of its valuable radio channels. I must admit that this afternoon's debate is probably one of the clinching arguments as to why Parliament should not be broadcast. The actual topic, which I think speaks for itself-one may wish to add a couple of other items to the end-is this:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to ensure the public release of the report by the Australian Federal Police of its investigations into breaches of the Commonwealth Electoral Act arising from the non-disclosure of an election campaign donation by Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd.

I too would have thought that the matter of public importance would have been better worded `alleged breaches'. Presumably the judgment has already been made. What I cannot understand is why the Opposition, when it wished to put down a matter of public importance, did not include Carpentaria Transport Pty Ltd. If it wants to release a report regarding an investigation of $10,000, one would have thought that it would want to release a report regarding an investigation of $300,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it was only $300,000. If there was any fairness, if what the Opposition was doing was upholding the integrity of the electoral laws, Senator Short would have called for the release of both of those reports. He did not do so and because he did not he condemns his case out of hand as being merely a case concerned with political mud-slinging, which I think the population of Australia is heartily sick and tired of.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to spend the time available to me in having a look at the disclosure laws. When items such as the one we have just seen occur it seems to me far better to address oneself to the substantive issue to see whether there may be ways in which we can overcome the problem and so lessen the likelihood of breaches taking place in the future. When my Party voted on an electoral reform package in 1978 one of the items included was:
All donations or assistance valued at more than $2,000 to any candidate, party or political group will be discloseable publicly. The sum will be indexed for changes in the value of money.
Further on it is stated:

Companies, trade unions, and any organisation which receives subscriptions or funds from its members, must clearly disclose in audited annual financial statements any donation made which it makes to the public electoral fund, political parties, candidates, or for any political purpose.

I think the first part is important. For 10 years our Party policy has been that all donations over a certain value should be disclosed. The difficulty the Daishowa case runs straight into is the distinction that has been made between campaign funds and funds for administrative purposes. I was on the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Electoral Reform at the time it presented its report on this matter and I acquiesced to that recommendation because at that stage the Liberal and National parties were fighting tooth and nail against any disclosure, not just disclosure for the campaigns but any disclosure of anything. So it seemed to me at that time-it seems a long time ago but it really was not; it was September 1983 when our report came in-that it was better to get something rather than nothing and that as time went on and problems emerged with the law as we have proposed it, hopefully public opinion would be such that people would press for increasing areas of disclosure by political parties.

I think that is what we have. It is one of the fruitful things that have come out of this episode. It was interesting, in going back, as I have done in the last few hours, and rereading the Press with regard to this episode to find that nowhere is it suggested that there should not be any disclosure. Those thoughtful articles in the Press that sought to find a way out of the problem all suggested we should get rid of the dichotomy between campaign funds and administrative funds. If we may be charitable enough to say that the Press is reflecting the general feeling outside-I am not sure whether it is but probably it does as well as any other organ in our community-there is not a move in the community to get rid of disclosure; there is a mood within the community to increase disclosure. I think now is the time for the Government to take note of that mood in the community and to seek to legislate. I am quite sure if it does so there will be a majority in this chamber to pass increased disclosure laws with regard to political funding. Although I think there would probably be opposition to it as well, the Australian Democrats would support it. We believe that by taking that extra step with regard to the administrative fund we will remove the problem that arose in this instance.

A number of other problems lurking in the Commonwealth Electoral Act have not been given as much attention. In fact, some of them have not been raised at all. I want to look at a couple of those now. I think if we are interested in cleaning up, tightening and finetuning the law to ensure that we do not have breaches, we must pay attention to the emerging problems. I would like to draw attention to the amounts of money that are paid in respect of public funding because this is the largest area which is open to a rorting of the disclosure provisions. The Australian Labor Party was allocated $8,428,000 under the title `public funding' for the 1984 and 1987 elections. The Liberal and National parties have $8,105,000 under that heading. This means that for the next election they will be able to put against expenditure $8m simply designated as public funding.

According to one piece of paper-I am not quite sure about the extent to which I should hold to this document because the figures are certainly not correct in respect of other items-the Labor Party spent over $7m in the last election campaign. This theoretically means that if the Labor Party does not spend any more than that the next time, it could actually disclose that all of its funds came from public funding. That was not the intent of the public funding provision; it was not the intent of the law; and it was not the intent of the disclosure Act. But that is where we are heading. As that public funding builds up after each election and the amounts get bigger and bigger, a political party is able to swallow all sorts of other donations. One can say, `All right, that means that the political parties might be trying to hide something'. Quite frankly, we are simply being absurd if we allow a law to rest on the fact that political parties do not want to hide something.

Senator Ray read out a number of examples-and I do not want to repeat them-of members of political parties who have said quite clearly that they have been trying to hide things. They have been quite happy to say publicly that they have been trying to do this. This is on the record. If we give someone the opportunity to do this, we have a bad law. Therefore, I think we need to do something about that exercise. One way of dealing with this matter would be to allow the Australian Electoral Commission to engage in random audits. This is a somewhat controversial proposition. After the 1984 election the Electoral Commission sought to engage in random audits. The national bodies of the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Tasmanian division of the Australian Democrats were chosen for random audit purposes. I can remember clearly that my Party certainly gave its okay to such an exercise when it was approached. I believe that the Labor Party also agreed with that arrangement but that the Liberal and National parties objected. Their objection was upheld on legal grounds by the Attorney-General's Department. In other words, the law did not give the Electoral Commission power to engage in random audits. So the Liberal and National parties were quite within their rights in objecting to this proposal.

When the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, which is now the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, looked at this item, we went through the whole exercise again, but there was not the will at that time to pursue the matter and give the Electoral Commission that additional power. I believe that we should look again at that item. I hope that the Government will look at it again and give the Electoral Commission the power to undertake random audits of political parties at any time, whether it be during a campaign or in the middle of the normal three-year period between elections-if we ever manage to get a three-year period between elections again in this country.

I think that that random audit procedure would fit very well with what we have given the Electoral Commission-that is, the power to act on its own cognisance to enforce the law. It is required to undertake the enforcement of the law. It must not simply ask the Government to do it; it is required to do it as an independent body. What we now need to do is give it more teeth to enable it to operate in a way that can be seen by the public as being fair and reasonable. The argument to date has been that we should rely on mutual trust and a whole range of other things. I think that is fine to this point. I am not complaining about what has happened up to this point, although many sections of the media have done so. As I see it, it is a gradual development. After all, in 1983 we did not have any disclosure. So we are moving, but we have to learn from our mistakes and we have to move forward. I think we now have the opportunity of moving forward in the electoral disclosure laws, of making them tighter and more transparent for the public.

The public has to maintain its faith in the political system. That may seem to be a rather naive and absurd proposition to put in a debate such as the one that has occurred until now, but I do not believe it is. If we give in to that type of despairing opportunity and say, `Well, everybody is going to throw mud at the political system, it's all bad and rotten and nobody will engage in it', we are damning the democratic process. We have to try and try again to get the political process up from its knees and operating in such a way that people can have faith in its integrity and in the people who are engaged in it. To do that, my Party welcomes the full disclosure of funds. We want that. We do it in terms of our Party constitution. We hope that other political parties want to do that also, to make as transparent as possible the operation of political parties in this country. I understand the problems that the Liberal and National parties put up at the time against disclosure but they have not actually come about in practice. I do not think there are any reasons any longer why any political party should stand in the way of having tough, open and transparent disclosure laws.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing a matter of public importance raised by Senator Short in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to ensure the public release of the report by the Australian Federal Police of its investigations into breaches of the Commonwealth Electoral Act arising from the non-disclosure of an election campaign donation by Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd.

The first thing to be said is that if it is not formally against standing orders for this allegation of breaches of the law to be made, certainly it is something which is quite improper to raise in this chamber. Indeed, it is quite clear that, recognising this, I believe, and in order to ensure that the Senate is not faced with the embarrassment of having a vote on this matter-which would have been the case if the matter had been raised by way of, say, an urgency motion or some such motion-the Opposition has decided to cast the matter as a matter of public importance, which does not require a vote. It would have been intolerable for this Senate chamber, composed as it is of elected representatives of the people from the various States and Territories, to set itself up as a tribunal to decide whether in fact breaches of the Commonwealth Electoral Act have occurred in this particular matter. To bring that allegation into the chamber by subterfuge, in other words, by way of a matter of public importance, is a very sad reflection on the Opposition, which obviously simply wishes to make allegations and political capital rather than deal with the matter in a fair-minded way.

The fact is that Senator Short has made an allegation that breaches of the Commonwealth Electoral Act have occurred. That is precisely what the Australian Federal Police investigation is being conducted to ascertain-to accumulate information, intelligence and evidence towards reaching a conclusion on that matter. I take it that Senator Short, in a sense, is trying to unduly influence-although I am sure they will not be influenced on iota-the investigating officers in that investigation. Why did not the Opposition cast the matter of public importance in terms of alleged breaches, purported breaches or apparent breaches? The fact is that the Opposition has chosen to allege that breaches have occurred whilst they have not been established by the Australian Federal Police or by the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) in a preliminary way. The final or correct tribunal, if breaches are said to have occurred, is the court-when a conviction is recorded. Senator Short and the Opposition want to set themselves up as a substitute for the courts of this country.

But not content with that, Senator Short, in the course of his remarks, alleged, concerning former minister Mick Young-and I took a note as he spoke-that he had falsely signed a Customs declaration. That is an allegation of a crime, a criminal offence. Mr Black, QC, who conducted the inquiry into Mick Young's involvement in the so-called Paddington Bear affair found:

There was no impropriety in the actions of the Hon. M. J. Young. Mr Young did not at any stage use or attempt to use his official position to his advantage or to divert any person from the proper and impartial performance of his duty. I express no conclusion as to whether any breach of the law of the Commonwealth may have occurred. My reasons for taking this course appear in Part XII of this report. It should not be inferred that I make any finding that a breach of the law of the Commonwealth may have occurred in the actions of the Hon. M. J. Young.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this the Black report?

—It is the Black report. The fact finding and expression of opinion by Mr Black stands in absolute contradistinction to the statement by Senator Jim Short during this debate. But it is not to be wondered at because his own leader, Mr John Howard, in an interview on the World Today on 4 February 1988, when asked by Heather Ewart: `Is it proper for you to speculate like this, publicly, Mr Howard, when it is the subject of a police inquiry?', replied:

SPEECH.PARA: There's no doctrine known to Australian or British law that says you can't canvass the merits of something like this while a police investigation is under way. That constraint only arises after some charge has been made.
It may not technically be sub judice but clearly it is prejudice in the real sense of the word-prejudgment by the Opposition in the terms of the matter of public importance-on this matter.

I will move to the questions raised more specifically in the matter of public importance. Unlike honourable senators on the other side, I do not intend to wander near and far. I will try to help the Senate understand the situation. The Australian Federal Police has acted in this matter on a specific request from the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC)-not from the Government. The Government is not the complainant in this matter. The independent Australian Electoral Commission, without any political interference, directive or decision whatsoever, has made the complaint. It is known, therefore, as the complainant. The AFP has taken up the matter. This request was communicated to the AFP by the Electoral Commission on 2 February 1988.

The AFP, at the end of its investigations, will decide to either recommend against prosecution or for prosecution. If a recommendation against prosecution is made, that will be contained in that confidential report which will be forwarded to the Director of Public Prosecutions. I will come to his role in a moment. If a recommendation for prosecution is made, quite clearly the sub judice rule will apply, even to Mr Howard and his Opposition, in relation to all persons and documents surrounding the matter. It would not, therefore, be the proper subject for debate in this chamber, nor would it be proper to disclose that report, because obviously the disclosure of the police report, while the matter is before the DPP and then the courts, would be quite out of order. The point is that the result of the Federal Police investigation, one way or the other, whatever the conclusion, will be made available to the Director of Prosecutions. I do not think it will even be made available to the Australian Electoral Commission, which is the complainant. The report, as I said, will be forwarded to the Director of Public Prosecutions. The independence of the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions is well known to all honourable senators. It is set up by statute of this Parliament. The booklet entitled Prosecution Policy of the Commonwealth dated January 1986 contains the following general statement:
Perhaps the most significant change-
in the setting up of the DPP-

is the effective removal of the prosecution process from the political arena by affording the Director an independent status in that process. The Attorney-General as First Law Officer is responsible for the Commonwealth criminal justice system. He remains accountable to Parliament for decisions made in the prosecution process notwithstanding that those decisions are now in fact made by the Director and lawyers of the DPP, subject to any guidelines or directions which may be given by the Attorney-General pursuant to section 8 of the Act.
One has only to look at the judicial recognition in Clyne v. the Attorney-General by Mr Justice Wilcox when he said:
Parliament has given to the Director the power to determine for himself whether an indictment shall be filed and whether a prosecution shall be discontinued.
He went on to say:
The evident intention was to divorce the Government, and the Attorney-General in particular, from day-to-day decision making in those areas.

I have given those quotations in full, which was perhaps somewhat tedious for those opposite. But I want to emphasise for those who may be listening that the Government will play absolutely no part in the decision whether or not to prosecute in relation to any matters arising out of this allegation of non-disclosure of an election campaign donation by Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd. Whether to prosecute is not a matter for government decision. If the DPP decides against prosecution it will be a matter for the DPP as to whether reasons are made public. If the DPP decides against prosecution, let it decide whether the reasons are to be made public.

The DPP has a quite unfettered discretion in this regard. The Government cannot properly direct the DPP to give or not to give reasons for non-prosecution. The Government and I, certainly, have no intention whatsoever of interfering with the discretion of the Director of Public Prosecutions in this regard. It is for the Director of Public Prosecutions, if he decides not to prosecute, to decide subsequently whether or not to make his reasons for non-prosecution available to the general public. That is his role, not the Government's. If he makes a decision to prosecute, as I said, the matter will then be before the courts. It will be sub judice and there will be no question of publishing any sort of police report. That would be quite prejudicial to those proceedings.

Given that sequence, it appears to me that the Government, represented either by me as the Minister responsible for the Australian Federal Police or Senator Ray as the Minister responsible for the AEC, will not be presented with the police report. I have now been Special Minister of State and then Minister for Justice for just over 12 months-plus this week, which feels like 12 months-and in all that time I cannot recall ever seeing a police report on my desk. I have had transmitted to me the conclusions of an investigation but I have never seen a police report. I do not want to see one and, as far as I am concerned, I have no reason to expect that the Australian Federal Police report into this matter will ever be made available to me as the Minister for Justice responsible for the Australian Federal Police.

We are dealing in this instance with quite autonomous institutions which are quite properly jealous of their integrity, namely, the Australian Electoral Commission as the complainant-not the Government-the Australian Federal Police as the investigating officers and the Director of Public Prosecutions, who will make the decision as to whether to prosecute. The Government will play no part in that series of decisions, which may or may not lead to a case being presented to a court for decision. The request that the Government make this particular report available I do not think will arise in the sense that I do not know which responsible Minister would ever have the report made available to him. The fact is that I think it would also be somewhat dangerous for a government to be in a position where it could decide from time to time which police report it might wish to divulge or disclose to the public and which not, particularly if a police report and then subsequently the decision of the DPP were that it did not reveal such matters or admissible evidence as should lead to a prosecution. For a government then to decide, nevertheless, to release the report publicly I would have thought would have filled senators with misgivings. Obviously one would be revealing much material of a prejudicial character which could well have the tendency to defame or impugn the integrity of persons who were caught up in or the subject of those investigations.

The short answer is, as I think was indicated by Senator Robert Ray at Question Time during the earlier part of this week, that though we were uncertain exactly where the report might go we were both fairly clear that it would not go to Senator Robert Ray as the Government Minister or to myself as the Minister for Justice. I do not believe, therefore, that the Government, even if it were so minded, can be in a position to ensure the public release of this report. I have indicated and constantly reiterated that the question of the release of reasons why a prosecution should not go ahead is in the hands of the quite independent Director of Public Prosecutions established by this Parliament. It is in the hands of Mr Ian Temby and his absolutely independent officials that that decision is entrusted. I believe that that is the proper course of events and procedures in a democracy and I would think it highly unlikely that the Government would ever be in a position to present this police report to the public.

The issue here is that there has been a clear, uncomplicated breach in the Harris-Daishowa matter. There can be no argument about that, and certainly no withdrawal from some phoney point of order by the desperate Minister on the other side of the Senate who got to the front bench only as the result of a sordid deal between the factions of the Labor Party. The reality is that there has been a breach, and the inquiry is to determine whether there should be any legal prosecutions emerging from that breach.
—It has not been determined that there has been a breach.

—The fact that the money was put into the wrong account is not seen by the Labor Party as a breach. I understand its morality. I can understand why it would respond in that way. If there is a clear instruction that the money should go to a campaign fund and then it is switched to the maintenance and administration fund, obviously the Labor Party would not regard that as a breach. That is evident from the way it has behaved. What arrogance and contempt for the law! Naturally the honourable senator does not regard it as a breach because the Labor Party itself shows that it does not. Mr Young is quoted on 3 February as saying that there had been no breach of the Act. The fascinating part reads:

SPEECH.PARA: He said there would only have been a breach if the money had been spent for campaign purposes after it had been directed to the Labor Party's administration account.

What happened was exactly the opposite. What they did was to divert money, clearly indicated and determinedly stated, that was supposed to go for the election campaign and for the Jim Snow campaign, who, I might say, was effectively snowed by his Party because he got only six grand out of the 10. Interestingly, Mr Young has said that there was no breach because even though it was used for the wrong purpose the Act says, according to him, that it is a breach only if the money had been spent for campaign after it had been directed to the Labor Party's administration account. He said that there had been a misunderstanding and that he shared in the misunderstanding that had taken place. The misunderstanding was with Mr Loosley.

Mick Young has declared himself innocent. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), Senator Ray and everyone have declared him innocent. They have been the judge and jury and have declared him innocent. Yet if we dare to say that there has been a breach of the Act we are somehow behaving disgracefully by suggesting that there is a possibility that someone has done something wrong by deliberately doing something that gets around the Act. The double standards, hypocrisy and dishonesty of this Labor Government in this matter and in its whole administration are exactly the same as the fraud and dishonesty that exist in the New South Wales State Labor Government. It is incredible. Only a week or so ago Michelle Grattan commented in the Age newspaper:

. . . the dubious handling of the woodchip donation reinforces all the bad things that are thought about the ALP Right wing. It brings back memories of the smell that emanated from the Wran Government.

How right she is. As I said last night in another debate, I can recall meeting Rex Jackson, who presently resides in the Berrima prison in New South Wales in what used to be a very good electorate when I represented it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They got rid of you.

—The electorate was divided up by Senator Bolkus's lot so that I could not get back. I saw Rex Jackson in the street outside the State office block. I was in company with a most reputable person who can certainly support my recollection of this matter. After I asked Rex Jackson how he would go with all the problems he was facing he said to me, `I think I'll be all right. In fact, I know I'll be all right. If I go they'll need a new Premier of New South Wales within a week'. What incredible prescience Mr Rex Jackson had because one week before the Jackson trial started, lo and behold, there was a new Premier of New South Wales. Whether that was pure coincidence I have no idea, but it does seem that Mr Jackson lost whatever leverage he thought he had in respect of not ending up in the cooler on the departure of Mr Neville Wran. I underline the point made by Michelle Grattan in the Age that there is that stench, that feeling-the smell that emanated from the Wran Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The New South Wales Right has argued that it is not all that bad, that Loosley would not have done anything wrong over the woodchip cheque because the machine would not sin on such a small scale so incompetently. That is the only defence: it was so incompetently done that it would not have done it. It was done because of desperation. It was done because there was an urgent need for something to be done to save Mick Young and Loosley was the fall guy. It may well be he was only too well aware of what the letter said and what Mr Young had instructed him to do either in the knowledge or without the knowledge of that letter. There are many facts which must come out in this matter which have not yet come out. That is why the police report must be revealed to the people of Australia, so that they can judge the morality of the Party which occupies the benches opposite and which is soon to be defeated in the State election in New South Wales because it has lost touch with the people and with morality.
